She hopes that she can get the amount she requested to further develop her business and harvest more rice to sell.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizers to sustain her rice production

loans.name: Leonida

texts.en:
Leonida, 49, is married and has six children. She lives in Gil Sanchez, Labason, Zamboanga del Norte.

She has a general store to earn a living and has had this business for one year. Each month, she earns 3,500 doing this type of work. She has requested a loan of 3,000 to purchase stock to sell in her general store.

Leonida became a member of PMPC this year, 2011. In the future, she hopes to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase stock to sell in her general store.

location.town: Gil Sanchez, Labason, Zamboanga del Norte

loans.name: Ararat

texts.ru: Арарат имеет участок земли, на котором расположены несколько теплиц. В прошлый раз он брал кредит и поставил четвертую большую теплицу. В этом году Арарат планирует поставить еще одну теплицу и сделать отопление на две теплицы. Также Арарат начал ремонт в своем доме, где он живет с женой и двумя детьми. Арарат любит свой бизнес и планирует развивать его дальше, так как этот бизнес является очень перспективным для данного региона.
texts.en: Ararat has a plot of land, where several greenhouses are located.  Last time he obtained a loan and installed a fourth large greenhouse.  This year, Ararat plans to install another greenhouse and provide heating for two greenhouses.  He also started to make repairs in his house, where he lives with his wife and two children.  Ararat loves his business and plans to develop it further because this business is very promising for this region.

loans.use: to build a new greenhouse and provide heating for two older greenhouses

loans.name: Dionesia

texts.en:
Dionesia is a 53 years old, married, and has 11 children. She is a farmer working in Trinidad, Bohol. Dionesia has been growing and selling rice for 20 years. She is able to provide for her family through her business. 

Dionesia is requesting a loan to purchase seeds and fertilizers and pay for labor. She hopes to own a bigger farm in the future. Dionesia does her best to feed her family and keep them healthy.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizers and pay for labor.

loans.name: Sreytoch

texts.en:
Sreytoch is 26 years old and married. She lives with her husband in Kampong Cham Province, Cambodia, an area known for rubber plantations. Sreytoch and her husband are farmers. They also raise pigs and water buffaloes. 

Sreytoch is requesting her first loan from KREDIT for $1,000 to purchase cows and buffaloes to sell. By doing so, her family is able to generate additional income.

loans.use: to cows cows and buffaloes to sell

loans.name: Rosita

texts.en:
Rosita is 36 years old and married. She lives in Culo Molave Zamboanga del Sur. Rosita has a general store, which she has had for almost one year. She earns 1,200 PHP a month.

Rosita is requesting a loan for 5,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase stock for her general store. Rosita has been a member of PMPC for almost nine months. In the future, she hopes to earn 2,000 PHP a month.

loans.use: to purchase stock for her general store.

loans.name: Odgerel

texts.en: Odgerel is 40 years old and lives with her husband in a ger (Mongolian yurt) in Selenge Province, Mongolia. Her husband is a chauffeur. Odgerel operates a vegetable and fruit trading business. She started her business in 2001. She is a trusted supplier of many shops, however she needs to build a storage area to save some supplies. She is a hard-working and diligent woman who says, "In the future we are planning to make our own grocery store." She is requesting 2,000,000 MNT to buy more fruits and vegetables and to save some supplies, because in the winter the prices will be high.

loans.use: to buy more fruits and vegetables

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To repair the family house.

loans.name: Ou

texts.en: Mrs. Ou, 43, is a hard-working farmer who earns a living by cultivating rice crops. She is from the Prey Chor district of Kompong Cham Province. She is married with six children, four of whom are single and live together with her. Ou is able to earn in the neighborhood of $2.50 each day to cover her daily expenses. This is Ou’s second loan from Kiva partner, HKL, and she wants to use it to buy rice seeds and to pay for laborers to cultivate her rice crops. In the future, she hopes to support some of her children to at least finish the high school level. She is very happy and thankful for the loan given to her because it will allow her to invest in her farming business and generate more income.

loans.use: to buy rice seeds and to pay for laborers to cultivate her rice crops.

loans.name: Gina

texts.en: Gina is 42 years old and lives in Pan-ay Diot, Tudela, Misamis Occidental. She is married with six children. Gina has a shop that sells noodles, canned goods, biscuits, etc. She has had this business for a year. She requested a loan of PHP 10,000 to purchase additional products such as noodles, canned goods, biscuits, etc. Gina has been a member of PMPC for a year. In the future, Gina hopes to send all of her children to school.

loans.use: to purchase additional products such as noodles, canned goods, biscuits, etc.

loans.name: Christine's Group

texts.en:
Christine's group is comprised of two hard-working women. Christine is 23 years old and lives in the town of Hoima in the Fort Portal region of Uganda. For the past three years, Christine has been working hard to manage her small shop, which sells clothes. 

To help expand her business, Christine has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more bundles of clothes for resale and will help Christine to generate greater profits and pay her children's school fees. Christine hopes that in the future she will be able to build a house. 

Christine is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Christine's future prospects by helping her to learn how to become a better entrepreneur.

loans.use: to purchase more bundles of clothes for resale

loans.name: Glenn

texts.en: Glenn is married with one child and lives in Canlambo, Larena, Siquijor. Glenn is a farmer, and she has backyard piggery to earn a living. She has been doing this for two years. Each month, she earns PHP 8,000 doing this type of work. She has requested a loan amounting to PHP 4,000 to purchase feed and medicines for her business. Glenn has been a member of Paglaum Multi Purpose Cooperative for seven months. In the future, Glenn would like to purchase more piglets from the profit of her business.

loans.use: to purchase feed and medicines for her piggery business

loans.name: Tu's Group

texts.en:
Tu was born in 1960. She lives in Kinh No, Uy No, Dong Anh, Ha Noi. She has one child. Her husband is retired. Mrs. Tu has a shop in the market. She sells clothes. She has this job for six years. She has a monthly income of about 4.000.000 Vietnamdong(VND). She needs a loan T. expand her business. She has participated in SEDA since 2010. This is the second time she borrowed a loan from SEDA. The last time she borrowed 5.014.000 VND and repaid this loan punctually. In this loan cycle she would like T. borrow 6.758.000 VND T. invest in her shop and T. buy more new clothes. She is the leader of 5 member group loan.

About the other borrowers in her group:
 Tuoi is 30 years old. She has two children. She wants T. borrow 6.758.000 VND T. buy grocery for her store.
 Phuong is 30 years old. She has one child. She wants T. borrow 6.758.000 VND T. breed pigs.
 Ly is 39 years old. She has three children. She wants T. borrow 6.758.000 VND T. buy more new clothes for her shop.
 Thuy is 29 years old. She has one child. She wants T. borrow 6.758.000 VND T. buy more new clothes for her shop.

loans.use: to invest in her shop and to buy more new clothes

loans.name: Erdenebaatar

texts.en: Erdenebaatar is 41 years old and lives with his wife and three kids in a ger (Mongolian yurt) in Bayanhongor Province, Mongolia. His wife helps with his business, and his kids are school students. Erdenebaatar operates a flour and rice trading business. He started his business in 2004 by renting a container in a market. He also works in a gas station. Now that the business is stable enough, he arranged to rent another container, however the supply is not enough to run a business. He is a strong and diligent man who says, "Now that my children are growing, I have to do everything I can to be able to pay for their education." He is requesting 2,000,000 MNT to buy flour at wholesale prices.

loans.use: to buy flour at wholesale prices

loans.name: Aliou

texts.fr:
Monsieur  Aliou  a 40 ans, marié et père de six enfants. Il réside avec son épouse et leurs enfants dans une grande famille traditionnelle élargie à Sanoubougou II dans la ville de Sikasso.
Aliou n’ayant pas eu la chance d’avancer dans les études, s’est vite initié au domaine  de la tôlerie avec la réparation des voitures accidentées et la confection des carrosseries, il y a de  cela cinq  ans. Il est beaucoup sollicité de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses prestations.
Dans le souci de mieux progresser son activité afin de satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida  de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y environ une année. Après plusieurs dépôts d’épargne volontaire, il est à son premier prêt individuel.
Avec ce premier prêt, il compte acheter,  5 feuilles de tôle 6,  5 feuilles de tôle 10, et 3 feuilles de tôle 20 . Il achète ces matériels en Côte d’Ivoire avant de les utiliser dans son atelier. 
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt.
texts.en:
Aliou is 40 years old, married and the father of 6 children. He lives with his wife and children in a traditional, extended family setting in the popular district of Sanoubougou II, in the town Sikasso. Aliou was unable to continue with his education but quickly found himself work as a sheet metal worker. He has been repairing cars and making car bodies for 5 years, and is much in demand due to the high quality of his work.

Wishing to develop his business and satisfy his growing customer demand, Aliou joined the microfinance instutition Soro Yiriwaso a year ago. Having made several voluntary savings deposits, he is now requesting his first individual loan. He will use the money to buy 5 sheets of metal (size 6), 5 sheets of metal (size 10) and 3 sheets of metal (size 20). He gets the materials that he uses in his workshop from the Ivory Coast.

Aliou predicts an average monthly profit of 100 000 francs, which he will use to pay the household expenses, pay off the interest on his loan and build up his working capital.

loans.use: to buy sheet metal.

loans.name: Loyas' Group

texts.en:
Loyas's group is comprised of five hard-working women. Loyas is 20 years old and lives in the town of Hima in Uganda. For the past five months, Loyas has been working hard to manage her restaurant, which prepares hot Ugandan meals for local customers. 

To help expand her business, Loyas has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more ingredients for her restaurant and will help Loyas to generate greater profits and improve the standard of living of her family. Loyas hopes that in the future she will be able to make enough profit to send her daughter to school. 

Loyas is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Loyas's future prospects by helping her to learn how to save.

loans.use: to purchase more ingredients for her restaurant

loans.name: Shahnoza

texts.ru: Шахноза мать-одиночка. Она разведена. Имеет на воспитании одну дочь. Для воспитания своей дочери она старается создать все условия, также  для хорошего обучения. На протяжении 10 лет она занимается купле- продажей мужской одежды. Товар она привозит из местных рынках. Сама имеет току на рынке. Бизнес востребованный, но для расширения бизнеса и дополнения новым товаром ей нужен займ. Она обращается к вам за помощью и надеется в вашей поддержке. Она хотела бы получить займ в размере 1700$ США для расширения товарооборота. Она надеется на помощь и благодарит вас за поддержку.
texts.en: Shahnoza is a single mother. She is divorced and has one daughter in foster care. For her daughter's upbringing, she has been trying to create all of the conditions for a good education. For 10 years she has been engaged in buying and selling men's clothing. She obtains her goods from the local market. She has a stall in the market herself. Her business is in high demand, but in order to grow her business and add new products, she is requesting a loan. She is turning to you for help and hopes for your support. She would like to receive a loan of $1700 to grow her inventory. She is hoping for help and thanks you for your support.

loans.use: Purchase new goods

loans.name: Justine's Group

texts.en:
Justine's group is comprised of five hard-working women. Justine is 18 years old and lives in the town of Kasese in Uganda. For the past four years, Justine has been working hard to manage her small business, which makes and sells jewelry and other handcrafts. 

To help expand her business, Justine has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more art supplies and will help Justine to generate greater profits and pay for medical expenses for her family. Justine hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a plot of land and build a house. 

Justine is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Justine's future prospects by helping her to lean how to save and manage finances.

loans.use: to purchase more art supplies

loans.name: Touch

texts.en: Touch, 23, lives with her husband in the Prey Veng Province. Currently, she is employed at a garment factory in Phnom Penh, while her husband is a construction worker building a house. This couple has one young child and would like to take out for a loan of US$1000 to purchase a motorbike and a trailer to attach in order to operate a motor-taxi.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike to operate a motor-taxi

loans.name: Ulziisaihan

texts.en: Ulziisaihan is 34 and lives with his wife and three children in a ger (Mongolian yurt) in Bayanhongor province, Mongolia. His wife runs a small garment retail business. His elder two children are school students, and his younger one goes to kindergarten. He started his taxi service in 2010 with his own car. His business was fine, and the income was enough for him to support his family until his car's engine broke. He wants to replace it with a new one and replace a few additional parts, as well. He is a hardworking and diligent man who says, "It has been horrible since my car broke down. My family is having crises. I have to make it right." He is requesting 1,200,000 MNT to purchase winter coat and to rent one more stall to expand his wife's business.

loans.use: To purchase a winter coat and to rent one more stall

loans.name: Sidh

texts.en: Sidh is 38 years old and lives with his wife in the Kampong Cham province. Since 1997, he has been a construction worker building houses. His wife is also a construction worker. In addition, she raises pigs. This couple has no children yet. They would like to request a loan of 300 USD to raise more pigs and to purchase food for the pigs.

loans.use: to raise pigs and to purchase food for the pigs

loans.name: Christopher

texts.en: Christopher is a 51-year-old married man living in Kyenjojo, Uganda. He has been operating a retail shop for ten years. He started the business with the money he earned as a government worker. His major challenge is price fluctuation and inadequate capital to purchase enough inventory. His personal goal is to build a permanent house, while his business dream is to expand his business into new markets. Christopher needs the loan to harvest maize.

loans.use: to harvest maize

loans.name: Alex

texts.en:
Alex is from Sagarejo, East Georgia. He is 33 years old, married, and lives with his family: wife Nona, and three children (12-year-old son and 10- and 3-year-old daughters). Alex works in a local factory that produces bricks. His monthly salary depends on the number of bricks produced by the factory. The bigger part of the family’s income comes from a small family dairy farm. They have three milk cows. Nona produces yogurt and cheese, which they sell. Their total average monthly income is 600 GEL. 

Alex requested credit for purchasing three calves. He will grow the calves and will expand the dairy farm. In a year Alex will already have six milk cows. Thus, the family will be able to produce and sell more dairy products. As a result, the income of the family will significantly increase. Alex and Nona will be able to create better living conditions for their three children.

loans.use: to purchase calves for expansion of the dairy farm

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has five children, four of whom are in school. Florence has a retail business selling tomoatoes at a food stall. She has been in this business for five years, and she works six days out of every week. Florence sells her products at the market. Florence has requested a loan of 1,000,000 UGX from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more boxes of tomatoes. She also generates additional income through sweeping for Kampala Capital City Authority and by operating a bicycle for hire.

The main business challenges for Florence include seasonality and defaulters. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start growing tomatoes and also to educate her children up to the university level. Florence lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity but does not have access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include feeding the family and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more boxes of tomatoes

loans.name: Diénéba

texts.fr:
Née vers 1961 à Bobo Dioulasso (Burkina Faso),  Diénéba est mariée et mère de 2 enfants. Elle résidant avec son époux et leurs enfants dans une grande famille traditionnelle à Kaboïla II, dans la ville de Sikasso.
Après plusieurs activités sans succès, cette femme s’est initiée depuis plus de vingt années à cette activité de petit commerce notamment à l’achat vente d’habillements (pagne wax, draps de lits, tissus brodés, etc.). 
Elle achète ses marchandises  au Burkina Faso auprès des commerçants grossistes avant de les revendre en gros et en détail dans la ville de Sikasso de façon ambulante à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes.
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso.  
Elle est à son deuxième crédit qui lui permettra d’augmenter son fonds de commerce afin d’acheter, 15 complets de tissus brodés, 10 pièces de pagnes wax et 10 draps de lit. 
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce crédit un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt
texts.en:
Diénéba was born circa 1961 in Bobo Dioulasso (Burkina Faso). She's married and the mother of two children. She lives with her husband and their children in a large traditional family in Kaboïla II, city of Sikasso.

After several unsuccessful businesses, she launched herself into retailing, more than twenty years ago, notably buying and selling clothing such as "pagnes wax" (colorful African cloth), bedsheets, embroidered fabrics, etc. 

She gets her supplies from wholesalers in Burkina Faso, and resell, retail or wholesale, as a traveling saleswoman in Sikasso. Her clientele comprises mostly women.

Eager to better meet an ever-increasing customer demand, she decided to join Kiva's partner, the MFI Soro Yiriwaso. She's seeking her second loan, to be used to bolster her working capital and buy 15 pieces of embroidered fabric, 10 pages wax, and 10 bedsheets.

With this loan, she foresees turning a monthly profit of XOF 100'000 (ca US$ 200), to be used mainly to bolster her working capital, help with the family expenses, and repay the loan.

loans.use: to buy 15 pieces of embroidered fabric, 10 pages wax, and 10 bedsheets

loans.name: Gbadaouya

texts.fr:
Gbadaouya est une femme âgé(e) de 39 ans. Elle est mariée å un  mécanicien à 04 roues. Elle a 03 enfants.  
Gbadaouya travaille comme revendeuse de céréales, d’ignames de pagnes et de glacières  depuis 1995. Elle vend dans sa maison à Hédzranawoé  après achat au Grand Marché de Lomé et aux marchés de l’intérieur.
Gbadaouya a requis son second crédit de WAGES afin d’acheter des pagnes, des ignames et des sacs de maïs.
Elle dit qu’avec les profits, Elle prévoit rendre sa famille heureuse.
texts.en:
Gbadaouya is a 39-year-old woman. She is married to an auto mechanic. She has three children.
Gbadaouya has worked as a retailer of cereals, yams, pagnes (brightly printed West African clothing), and iceboxes since 1995. She sells her products at home in Hédzranawoé after buying them at the Grand Market in Lomé and at markets in the interior of the country.
Gbadaouya has requested her second loan from WAGES in order to buy pagnes, yams, and sacks of maize.
She says that with her profits, she intends to make her family happy.

loans.use: To buy pagnes (brightly printed West African clothing), sacks of maize, and iceboxes.

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda is 45 years old, married, and has two children.  She lives in Tanza, Cavite City, Philippines. Together with her husband and children, she manages their household while operating her curtain business. She works hard to provide income for their everyday expenses.  

Erlinda makes curtains and other products from fabric that she buys from her supplier. She offers curtains, blankets, and other home trappings. She sells her products in the community market. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns approximately 300 PHP in sales every day.

Erlinda is requesting a loan for 8,000 PHP to help her continue operations of her business. She will use the loan to buy more quantities of raw materials such as fabric, thread, and other items needed in her business. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands.  

Erlinda hopes her business grows and dreams of giving her children a high quality education through all her hard work. She meets weekly with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work and study the word of God.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to purchase raw materials needed in her business.

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen is 50 years old and lives in Tinago, Siquijor, Philippines. She is married with one school-age child.

Helen operates a grocery store to earn a living.  Each month she earns PHP 10,000 doing this type of work. She has requested a loan amounting to PHP 7,000 to purchase more stock for her general store business.

Helen has been a member of Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative for 9 months.  In the future, Helen hopes to expand her business.

Paglaum

loans.use: To purchase more stock for her general store business

loans.name: Sopheak

texts.en: Sopheak, 26, is married and lives in the Kampong Cham province. She started selling groceries and sugar cane juice in 2010 to support her daily expenses. Her husband works transferring data from the PC to a hand phone. This couple has one young child. To earn more money to improve her standard of living, she is asking for a loan of US $800 to add her stock of her groceries.

loans.use: to buy more groceries to sell

loans.name: Janet

texts.en: Janet lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has five children, three of whom are in school. Janet has a business selling charcoal.  She has been in this business for 10 years and she works six days out of every week.  Janet sells her products at the market by means of wholesale/retail. Janet has requested a loan of 1,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of charcoal. The main business challenge(s) for Janet include seasonality and transportation. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start selling at wholesale only and to educate her children up to university. Janet lives in a home that she rents. She has access to electricity but not piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include rent, feeding the family and school fees.

loans.use: To buy more bags of charcoal

loans.name: Hamidou Ousmane

texts.fr:
Hamidou est un célibataire de 23 ans résidant dans une famille traditionnelle élargie  dans la ville de Sikasso.
Hamidou n’ayant pas eu la chance de progresser dans les études s’est très vite initié depuis près de dix ans à cette activité d’achat et de vente de téléphones portables et leurs accessoires (façades, batteries, chargeurs, écouteurs, etc.). Son activité est menée dans sa propre boutique à la gare routière de Sikasso avec une clientèle composée essentiellement des voyageurs et surtout de transporteurs. Il est beaucoup sollicité de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, Il décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il bénéficié de trois crédits tous correctement remboursés. Il sollicite ce quatrième crédit pour acheter à Bamako, 40 téléphones portables de marques différentes, 3 cartons de façades, une quinzaine de chargeurs, 20 paquets de carte mémoire, 15 cartons de batterie, 10 douzaines d’écouteurs de différentes sortes, une dizaine de montres différentes et des ceintures. 
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 350 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt
texts.en:
Hamidou is a 23-year-old single man who lives in an extended traditional family in the city of Sikasso. 

Having not had the opportunity to pursue his studies, Hamidou learned early on the business of buying and selling mobile phones and accessories (skin cases, batteries, chargers, headphones, etc.), an activity he has been practicing for nearly 10 years. He conducts his business in his own shop at the Sikasso bus station and his clientele consists mainly of travelers and carriers. He is in high demand due to the quality of his merchandise. 

Eager to meet the needs of his growing customer base, he decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, where he has previously received three loans, all properly repaid. 

He is seeking a fourth loan to go to Bamako to purchase 40 mobile phones of various brands, 3 boxes of skin cases, about 15 chargers, 20 packs of memory cards, 15 boxes of batteries, a dozen set of headphones in different styles, a selection of watches and some belts. 

He hopes to earn a monthly profit of 350,000 FCFA, which he will use primarily to increase his working capital, to help with the household expenses, and to pay the interest on the loan.

loans.use: to buy mobile phones and accessories for resale

loans.name: Oliver

texts.en:
Oliver is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kasese in Uganda. She is married and has two children. For the past two years, Oliver has been working hard to manage her small business selling palm oil. 

To help expand her business, Oliver has requested a loan of 150,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more palm oil for resale and will help Oliver to generate greater profits and pay for medical expenses for her family. Oliver hopes that in the future, she will be able to buy a plot of land and build a house. 

Oliver is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Oliver's future prospects by helping her to learn how to read.

loans.use: to purchase more palm oil for resale

loans.name: Sofiya

texts.ru: София прекрасная хозяйка. Она на воспитании имеет пятерых детей. Муж глава семьи работает колхозником. Семья трудолюбивая. Они все вместе стараются для создания лучших жилищных условий и получения образования. Несмотря на свой возраст она не сидит на месте. На рынке она продает молочные продукты. Она закупает продукцию на селе продает в городе. Её продукция очень востребована. На полученный доход они и живут. Для закупа еще больше товара нужны средства. Поэтому она хочет получить займ в размере 3000 сомони. Она обращается к добрым милосердным людям за помощью. Надеется получить займ и расширить свой товарооборот.
texts.en: Sofiya is a wonderful housewife. She is raising five children. Her husband the head of the family works as a farmer. Their family is hardworking. Together they try to make better living conditions and provide education. Despite her age Sofiya does not sit still. She sells milk products on the market. She buys the products in the village and sells in the town. Her products are in high demand. They spend the profit on daily living. She needs more money to buy more milk products. This is why she wants to take out a loan in the amount of 3000 somoni. Sofiya is asking kind and merciful people for help. She hopes to get the loan and increase the commodity turnaround.

loans.use: to buy milk products.

loans.name: Aku

texts.fr:
Aku est une femme  âgé(e) de 35 ans. Elle est célibataire et a  02 enfants en charge.
Aku travaille comme restauratrice. Elle achète au Grand Marché de Lomé et répond à la demande de la population au Campus Universitaire de Lomé.
Aku a requis son second  crédit de WAGES afin d’acheter du riz, du maïs et divers.
Elle dit qu’avec les profits, Elle prévoit assurer un avenir meilleur à ses enfants vu qu’elle prend en charge ses derniers.
texts.en:
Aku is a 35-year-old woman. She is single and has two children to support. 

Aku works in the restaurant business. She purchases supplies from the Lomé grand market and caters to demand from people at the University of Lomé campus.

Aku has requested her second loan from WAGES to purchase rice, corn and sundries.

She says she will use the profits to give her children a better future, as she is responsible for taking care of them.

loans.use: to buy rice, corn and sundries.

loans.name: Mahoua

texts.fr:
Âgée de 44 ans, Mahoua est mariée et mère de 7 enfants. Elle  réside avec son époux et leurs enfants dans une grande famille traditionnelle à Sikasso.
Après plusieurs activités sans succès, Mahoua s’est initiée depuis plus de dix années aux activités de petit commerce notamment à l’achat et à la vente d’habillements (pagne wax,  tissus brodé, etc.) et des sacs à main. Elle achète ses marchandises sur places auprès des commerçants grossistes de Sikasso et Bamako avant de les revendre à sa place au marché où ses marchandises sont beaucoup sollicitées de sa clientèle (composée essentiellement de femmes de ménage et vendeuses de condiments) pour leurs qualités.
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. 
Après avoir correctement remboursé le premier prêt, elle est à son deuxième crédit qu’elle compte utiliser pour augmenter son fonds de commerce afin d’acheter 20 complets de tissus brodés, 15 pièces de pagne wax, 15 sacs à main et des colliers de femmes. 
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce deuxième crédit un bénéfice mensuel de 175 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mahoua is 44 years old, married and the mother of 7 children. She lives with her husband and their children in a large traditional family in Sikasso. After trying several activities without success, for the last 10 years Mahoua has been working as a small-scale retailer, buying and selling clothing supplies (wax cloth known as "pagne," embroidered fabric, etc) and handbags. She buys these items locally from wholesalers from Bamako and Sikasso then re-sells at the market where her products are very much in demand for their high quality. Most of her customers are cleaning ladies and sellers of condiments. 

In order to meet the demand from her growing number of customers, she decided to join micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso. Mahoua has properly repaid the first loan and is now on her second, which she will use to increase her working capital so she can  buy 20 outfits made from embroidered fabric, 15 lengths of "pagne," 15 handbags and women's necklaces. [With this first loan] she expects to make a profit of 175,000 CFA francs a month which she will mostly use to contribute to family expenses and  pay interest on the loan. The rest will be reinvested in her business.

loans.use: to buy various items.

loans.name: Borin

texts.en: Borin, 49, is a widow living with her daughter in the Kandal province. She grows and sells vegetables and her daughter is a garment factory worker. Borin is asking for a loan of US $1,000 to purchase a water pump.

loans.use: to buy a water pump to water vegetables

loans.name: Mamadou

texts.fr:
Né vers 1968 à Sikasso, Monsieur Mamadou est marié  et réside avec son épouse et leurs enfants dans une grande famille traditionnelle élargie dans la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur Mamadou après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans succès,  s’est initié au domaine de l’aviculture depuis l’année 2006. Il dispose d’une  ferme non loin de la ville de Sikasso sur la route RN7 où il y a des centaines de tête d’oiseaux (poules, pintades, oies, dindons, pigeons, etc.). Il est beaucoup sollicité de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses volailles qui sont de bonnes qualités et bien suivies par des vétérinaires qualifiés. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il a 2 ans environ et avec qui il à déjà bénéficié de trois prêts.
 Il sollicite ainsi ce quatrième prêt individuel pour acheter, des poussins, des médicaments et nourritures de sa base cour.
 Avec ce prêt il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 175 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Born around 1968 in Sikasso, Mr. Mamadou is a married man who resides with his wife and their children in a large traditional extended families in Sikasso City (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After having run several businesses unsuccessfully, he has become familiar with the domain of poultry since 2006. 

Mr. Mamadou has a farm not far from Sikasso City on Route RN7 where there are hundred of birds (hens, Guinea hens, geese, turkeys, pigeons, etc.) He is much in demand by his customers for the quality of his birds, which are good quality and watched over by qualified veterinarians. 

To satisfy his burgeoning customer base, Mr. Mamadou decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso about two years ago. He has already benefited from three loans with it. He is thus requesting this fourth individual loan to buy chicks and some farmyard medicines and feed. 

With this loan, he envisions making a monthly profit of 175,000 francs CFA that will be used essentially to help with family expenses and to cover the interest on his loan. The rest will be invested in his business.

loans.use: to buy chicks and some medicine

loans.name: Isabel

texts.en:
This is Isabel, 28, a resident of Tanza, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Eduardo, her business partner, and a mother to her two children. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Isabel operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries, and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5 worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns money by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue the operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 19,000 loan. She will be using the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, beverages, and other products needed in her business. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Isabel hopes her business grows in the coming years and dreams to be able to give her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.fr:
Âgée de 31 ans, Madame Mariam est mariée et mère de trois. Elle vit avec son époux à Médine- Sikasso.
Après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans succès, elle s’est initiée depuis plus de deux ans à cette activité de vente d’oignons au nouveau  marché de Médine dont elle dispose d’une  table où elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a deux année. Elle est à son quatrième crédit qui lui permettra d’augmenter son fonds de commerce afin d’acheter 20 sacs d’oignons (10 sacs de petites graines et 10 sacs de grosses graines) auprès d’une femme qui lui vend en gros au comptant et à crédit.
 Ses marchandises sont vendues au comptant, en détail et à crédit à une clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes.
Avec ce quatrième crédit elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 100 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce de ses dépenses, contribuer aux dépenses familiales et payer les intérêts de son prêt .
texts.en:
Ms. Mariam, 31 years old, is a married mother of three children. She lives with her husband in Médine-Sikasso. After having run several businesses without success, she has for over two years become familiar with this business of selling onions at the new market in Médine, where she has a table. There, she is much in demand by her customers for the quality of her products. 

To satisfy her burgeoning customer base, Ms. Mariam decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso two year ago. She is on her fourth loan, which will enable her to increase her business capital in order to buy 20 sacks of onions (10 sacks of small and 10 sacks of large) from a woman who sells in bulk and accepts cash or credit. Ms. Mariam sells her merchandise retail, for cash or on credit, to a customer base composed essentially of women. 

With this fourth loan, Ms. Mariam envisions making an average monthly profit of 100,000 francs CFA that will be used essentially to increase her business capital, to help with family expenses, and to cover the interest on her loan.

loans.use: to buy condiments

loans.name: Dilfuza

texts.ru: Дилфуза второй год занимается продажей сезонных товаров. Она не замужем. Но поддержки своих родителей и занимается бизнесом. Она хочет обустроить свою жизнь и быть независимой. Полученный доход она вкладывает в бизнес. Она хочет получить займ в размере 6000 сомони для пополнения ассортимента своего товара. Она  надеется на получение займа и благодарна за помощь.
texts.en: Dilfuza has been involved in selling seasonal goods for the second year now.  She is not married.  Dilfuza is involved in this business to support her parents.  She wants to also provide for her life and become independent.  She invests her profit into the business.  Dilfuza wants to obtain a loan in the sum of 6000 somoni to refill her merchandise inventory.  She hopes to get this loan and is grateful for the help.

loans.use: to refill her merchandise inventory

loans.name: Vicent

texts.en: Vicent is a 37 year old married man with six children living in Kyenjojo, Uganda. He has been in the agricultural sector for six years. His major challenge is seasonal weather and his dreams are educating his children plus constructing houses for renting. Vicent needs the loan to pay workers who are weeding his Irish potatoe and maize garden.

loans.use: to weed his irish potatoe and maize garden.

loans.name: Kosar's Group

texts.en:
Kosar has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her husband who is a driver by profession and provides transportation services to his clients. He is an expert driver and drives his vehicle very carefully. With the loan he will repair his vehicle as its engine is causing problems and needs repair works urgently. By repairing his vehicle he will be able to provide better quality transport services to his clients and will also be able to save his valuable business asset.

Kosar is a mother of four sons, tow of them works as laborers while the third one is a master tailor. Her youngest son stays at home and looking for work these days. Kosar is very supportive and sews clothes for her neighboring clients on order. The income she earns helps her pay her utility bills.
She is confident about her husband’s business success after the loan investment.

loans.use: to repair his vehicle for his transportation business

loans.name: Minata

texts.fr:
Minata  est une veuve de 56 ans vivant avec ses 4 enfants dans la grande famille de son défunt mari à Sikasso.
Minata  après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès,  s’est initiée à cette activité de restauration il  ya environ six  ans. Elle mène son activité devant une école tous les jours où elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle composée d’ élèves et de professeurs pour la qualité de ses plats. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis plus d’un an. 
Après deux prêts individuels bien remboursés, elle sollicite un troisième prêt individuel lui permettant d’acheter 5 sacs de pomme de terre, 40kg de viande de bœuf, 60kg de poissons frais, 10litres d’huile alimentaire, 3 paquets de cube maggie, 2 bidons de vinaigre, 25 sachets d’Attièkè, 2 sacs de charbon de bois, 30 miches de pain et des bananes (Aloko).
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 130 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour  contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en: Minata is a 56-year-old widow living in Sikasso with her four children and the family of her deceased husband. After having run several business without success, she became familiar with this restaurant business about six years ago. She operates every day in front of a school, where she is much in demand by her customers, who are students and teachers, for the quality of her dishes. To satisfy her burgeoning customer base, Minata decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso over a year ago. After two individual loans, which were indeed repaid, she is requesting a third individual loan enabling her to buy: 5 sacks of potatoes, 40 kg of beef, 60 kg of fresh fish, 10 liters of cooking oil, 3 packets of Maggie bouillon cubes, 2 containers of vinegar, 25 pouches of attièkè (a cassava-based couscous), 2 sacks of charcoal, 30 loaves of bread, and some bananas (aloko). Minata envisions making a monthly profit of 130,000 francs CFA that will be used essentially to help with family expenses and to cover the interest on her loan. The rest will be invested in her business.

loans.use: to buy supplies for her restaurant

loans.name: Det

texts.en:
Mrs. Det, age 43, is a hard-working and responsible housewife who always cares for her family. Agriculture is her livelihood, from which she earns a profit of $2.00 each day. One of her daughters helps her earn income by working in a garment factory in Phnom Penh city, receiving a monthly salary of $100. 

Det has talked with her daughter and she decided that she will create a fruit selling business from a rented booth in front of the garment factory. This new project will need capital of around $500 to start, yet she doesn’t have enough money. Thus, she is taking out a loan from HKL and Kiva to pay for a rented booth and to purchase a stock of fruit to sell. She hopes to sell out all her fruit and to grow this business in the future.

loans.use: to pay for a rented booth and to purchase a stock of fruit to sell.

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is widowed and has three children, all of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members. Juliet has a business of a retail shop. She has been in this business for four years, and she works seven days out of every week. Juliet sells her products in a shop, by means of retail. 

Juliet has requested a loan of 700,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of sugar, boxes of soap, and cooking oil. The main business challenges for Juliet include seasonality and transportation. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start selling wholesale only and also to own a delivery van to ease her transportation. Juliet lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity and doesn't have access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include rent, feeding the family, and school fees.

loans.use: to buy more bags of sugar, boxes of soap, cartons of salt, and cooking oil

loans.name: Ana

texts.en:
This is Ana, 35--a resident of Tanza, Cavite City, Philippines. She is married to Joseph, a janitor, and is a mother to her only child. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Ana operates a rug-making business. She mainly offers rugs, from round palm-sized ones to much larger doormats, and also braided quilts, bed sheets, and other crafts that most rug-makers make every day. As rugs are a major part of Filipino housekeeping and cleaning, rugs are some of the most common products that can be bought, sometimes even from a peddler while you are riding in a speeding jeepney down the highway. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of PHP 250 in sales every day.

To help her continue the operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 8,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of raw materials like fabric, thread, and other materials for her business. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Ana dreams to be able to give her family a good future through all her hard work with her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week, where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for raw materials needed in her business.

loans.name: Akou

texts.fr:
Akou est une femme  âgé(e) de 41 ans. Elle est mariée à un tailleur et ont ensemble 03 enfants.
Akou travaille comme revendeuse d’alimentation générale depuis 2000. Elle vend de façon ambulante et en même temps à domicile. Ses approvisionnements se font à Hédzranawoé. 
Akou a requis son second  crédit de WAGES afin d’acheter des produits d' alimentations générales (riz, huile végétale, sucre). Elle veut accroitre son activité dans les bénéfices réalisés.
texts.en:
Akou is a 41-year-old woman. She is married to a tailor and they have three children together.

Akou has been selling basic groceries since 2000. She sells both as a street vendor and from her home. She gets her supplies in Hédzranawoé.

Akou requested her second loan from WAGES in order to buy basic groceries (rice, vegetable oil, sugar). She wants to expand her business with the profits.

loans.use: to buy basic groceries.

loans.name: Oumou

texts.fr:
Madame Oumou a plus 42 ans et vit avec son époux et ses 7 enfants , à Wayerma I, le centre ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès, Madame Oumou s’est initiée à cette activité de restauration depuis plus de quinze ans. Son activité est menée toutes les nuits devant le domicile conjugal à Wayerma I Sikasso où elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant cinq ans. Après 8 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) dans une association des femmes de son quartier, elle est à son huitième prêt individuel, tous ses prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Elle compte acheter avec ce présent prêt: 35 poulets, 3 sacs de pomme de terre, 30 paquets de spaghettis, 45kg de poissons frais, 50kg de haricot, 40 sachets d’Attièkè, 35kg de haricot vert et un stock de banane (Aloko). Elle achète ses marchandises sur place.
Les marchandises sont vendues au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée de femmes, de jeunes (célibataires) surtout de noctambules. 
Elle envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 175 000FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour  contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mrs. Oumou is 42 years old. She lives with her husband and their seven children in Wayerma I, in downtown Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

After attempting many activities without success, Mrs. Oumou started working in the restaurant business over fifteen years ago. She works every night in front of the family residence, and she is in high demand due to the quality of her products.

In order to satisfy a growing customer base, she decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso five years ago. After eight group loans as a member of a local women’s association, she is now seeking an eighth individual loan. All previous loans were correctly repaid. 

She will use this new credit to buy 35 chickens, 3 bags of potatoes, 30 packages of spaghetti, 45 kg of fresh fish, 50 kg of beans, 40 packets of Attieke, 35 kg of green beans and a supply of bananas (Aloko). She buys her stock locally.

She sells for cash and credit to a clientele composed of women, young unmarried people, and especially night owls. She plans to earn a monthly profit of 175,000 FCFA that she will use primarily to contribute to family expenses and pay the interest on the loan. Any remainder will be reinvested in the business.

loans.use: to buy food supplies for her restaurant business

loans.name: Boubacar

texts.fr:
Monsieur Boubacar est âgé de plus de 35 ans,  marié et père de deux enfants. Il habite le quartier Kaboïla I-Kélétiguila, le centre ville de Sikasso.
Monsieur Boubacar après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans succès,  s’est initié  depuis plus de trois ans à cette activité de commerce d’articles divers. Il dispose d’une boutique à Wayerema où il mène cette activité d’achat et de vente d’articles tels  les Jeans, Ferardines, Abacos, Chaussures, souliers,  ceintures etc. Il est beaucoup sollicité de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a environ un  an. Il a bénéficié de 2 crédits qui ont été tous correctement remboursés. 
 Il sollicite ainsi ce troisième crédit pour pouvoir acheter 10 paires de chaussures “Ferardine”, 5 complets de veste “Abacos”, 5 paires de souliers, une douzaine de ceintures, 15 pantalons de qualité différentes et 10 chemises différentes. Il s’approvisionne à Bamako avant de les revendre de façon ambulante, au comptant et à crédit, dans les différentes structures professionnelles de Sikasso ville et souvent jusqu’à Baguinéda sur la route de Ségou.
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 200 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Boubacar is more than 35 years old, married, and the father of two children. He lives in the Kaboïla I-Kélétiguila neighborhood in downtown Sikasso. After running several unsuccessful businesses, he launched himself into retail more than three years ago. 

He has a shop in Wayerema, where he buys and sells various items such as jeans, belts, shoes (Ferardine, …), and Abacos vests. He's very much sought after by his clientele thanks to the quality of his products.

To meet an ever-increasing customer demand, he decided to join Kiva's partner, Soro Yiriwaso, approximately one year ago. He has already obtained two loans, which were both repaid without problems.

He's seeking his third loan in order to buy 10 pairs of "Ferardine" shoes, 5 "Abacos" vests, 5 pairs of shoes, a dozen belts, 15 pairs of trousers of various quality, and 10 different shirts.

He gets his supplies in Bamako, and resell as a traveling salesman, for cash and on credit, in the various professional institutions in Sikasso, and often as far as Baguinéda, on the road to Ségou.

With this loan, he foresees turning a monthly profit of XOF 200'000 (ca US$ 400), to be used mainly to help paying the family expenses and repay the loan. He will reinvest the remainder in his business.

loans.use: to buy 15 pairs shoes, 5 vests, a dozen belts, 15 pairs of trousers, and 10 shirts.

loans.name: Gulnara

texts.ru: Гульнаре 47 лет, замужем. Вместе с мужем воспитали троих детей. Закончив факультет журналистики, Гульнара проработала в редакции центральной местной газеты. В 1994 году, переехав в село Арал, стала заведующей  местной библиотеки, где и работает по сей день.  В качестве дополнительного источника дохода, семья Гульнары занимается животноводством. Начатое с суммы в 20,000 сом (KGS) хозяйство сегодня приносит около 6,000 сом (KGS) в месяц от продажи молочных продуктов.   В целях дальнейшего увеличения поголовья скота, Гульнара обратилась в компанию «Бай  Тушум и Партнеры» за кредитом в сумме 50,000 сом (KGS) на покупку нетели и грубых коров. Доходы от кредита Гульнара планирует вложить в увеличение поголовья, что позволит ей увеличить свое хозяйство.
texts.en: Gulnara is 47 years old.  Together with her husband, they raised three children.  After graduating with a journalist major, Gulnara worked in an editorial department of the central, local newspaper.  She moved to the Aral village in 1994 and became the head of the local library, where she still works to this day.  Gulnara's family is involved in animal husbandry as a way to have an additional source of income.  This business was started with a sum of 20,000 som (KGS) and brings in about 6,000 som (KGS) per month today from the sales of dairy products.  In order to further increase livestock headcount, Gulnara requested a loan in the sum of 50,000 som (KGS) from the "Bai-Tushum and Partners" company for the purchase of heifers and cows.  Gulnara plans to invest the profits from the loan into increasing the headcount, which will allow her to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Amelia

texts.en:
This is Amelia, 42, a resident of Tanza, Cavite City, Philippines. She is a widow with one child. She, together with her child, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.  

Amelia maintains a direct selling business. She sells clothing, footwear, undergarments, cosmetics and other products through the popular direct selling brands like Avon, Fuller life, Natasha, Boardwalk, Marikina Shoe Exchange, and other direct selling brands. A customer's order is bought in cash by the dealer and then given to the customer with a one-month-to-pay credit. Dealer’s prices are lower than those in the catalogue, and these are the profits that dealers are receiving as their income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of 800 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every week.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 8,000 loan. She will be using the loan to buy merchandise for her customers. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Amelia fervently hopes to grow her business in the coming years. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for merchandise for her customers

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy pesticides and seedlings

loans.name: Yaya

texts.fr:
Monsieur Yaya  est agé de plus 40 ans, marié et père de deux enfants. Il réside avec sa famille dans sa propre maison à Banconi, Sikasso (troisième région administrtive de la république du Mali).
 Après une formation en thérapeute, il s’est vite initié aux activités d’achat et de vente des produits pharmaceutiques depuis plus de vingt ans. Avec une telle expérience dans ce domaine, il jouit d’une forte réputation et accueille beaucoup de commandes, mais les ressources nécessaires pour satisfaire ces besoins font défaut. Ainsi, il décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle il a déjà bénéficié  de 4 prêts individuels, tous correctement remboursés. Dans le cadre de toujours mieux améliorer son activité, il sollicite un cinquième prêt qui lui permettra d’acheter 20 cartons de Manames, 10 cartons d’Aloé, 12 bidons d’inzam indien, 5 cartons de nifroxacin et 5 cartons de liptons. 
Sa source d'approvisionnement principale est à Lomé (république de Togo) grâce au programme de crédit de Soro Yiriwaso. Auparavant, il approvisionnait auprès de son fournisseur à Koutiala pour venir les revendre à Sikasso dans sa pharmacopée située à la gare routière de Sikasso à une clientèle composée de voyageurs et surtout de  routiers. Certains de ses clients payent au comptant, d’autre à crédit. 
Avec ce prêt, il envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 375 000 FCFA. Avec ces bénéfices réalisés, il compte résoudre l’essentielle de ses dépenses, celles de sa famille, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Yaya is over 40, married with two children. He resides with his family in his own house in Banconi, Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

After training as a therapist, he quickly began buying and selling pharmaceutical products and has been doing so for over twenty years. With so much experience in this domain, he has a strong reputation and gets many orders, but he lacks the necessary resources to meet the demand.

So he decided to join the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution which has already granted him four individual loans, all properly reimbursed. Wanting to further improve his business activity, he is now requesting a fifth loan that will enable him to buy 20 boxes of Manames, 10 cartons of Aloe, 12 cans of Indian inzam, 5 cartons of nifroxacin and 5 cartons of Lipton.

His main source of supply is in Lome (Republic of Togo) thanks to the Soro Yiriwaso credit program. Previously, he replenished his stock supply from his supplier in Koutiala. He resells the products in his pharmacy located at the Sikasso bus station, to a clientèle primarily composed of passengers and in particular drivers. Some of his customers pay cash, other are offered credit.

With this loan he expects a monthly profit of 375,000 FCFA. The profits will serve to deal with most of his expenses, those of his family, pay interest on the loan and reinvest the rest in his business activity.

loans.use: Buy pharmaceutical drugs

loans.name: Naris

texts.ru:
Нарис 30 лет, замужем и воспитывает троих детей, старшие дети учатся в школе.  Супруг работает в « Кыргыз почтасы» почтальоном. В целях увеличения дохода семьи, два года назад Нарис решила начать свой собственный бизнес в торговле, используя при этом стартовую сумму в 40,000 сом (KGS). Открытие небольшого магазина с промышленными и хозяйственными товарами поддержала и мама Нарис, оказавшая помощь в предоставлении помещения под магазин.  Доходы от бизнеса позволили Нарис сделать ремонт в квартире и купить бытовую технику. 
 В целях дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса, Нарис обратилась в компанию «Бай – Тушум и Партнеры» за кредитом в сумме 30,000 сом (KGS) на расширение товара. Сейчас Нарис прилагает все усилия , чтобы воплотить свою мечту – дать детям хорошее образование.
texts.en: Naris is 30 years old, married and raising three children. The older children are in school. Her husband works as a mail carrier for the Kyrgyz Post. In order to increase her family’s income, two years ago Naris decided to launch her own sales business, using a starting capital of 40,000 KGS. Naris’s mother, who helped with obtaining store premises, helped her open a small store with household goods and various general merchandise. The income from her business allowed Naris to do renovations in the apartment and to buy home appliances. In order to develop her business further, Naris turned to “Bai Tushum and Partners” for a loan in the amount of 30,000 KGS for expanding her  assortment of goods. At present Naris strives very hard to realize her dream and provide good education for her children.

loans.use: to  expand her assortment of goods

loans.name: Sokorn's Group

texts.en:
Sokorn, 49, is married with four children. Two of her kids are married, the older kid works at her business and the youngest kid is still in school. Living in a rural area of Thmor Koul district, Sokorn has been raising pigs for almost five years. To better feed her family, she also runs a small store in the village selling Chinese noodles and coffee. 

Sokorn leads a group of two female members. She has been with VisionFund for three loan cycles while her group member is just with VisionFund for this cycle. She completely repaid her loans with VisionFund. The loans from VisionFund help her to have a decent living standard and buy a motorbike. 

Now she is requesting a fourth loan. She will use this loan to buy feed for her pigs. With this loan, she hopes her pigs will be healthy and fat, which will enable her to earn more income to build some savings to build a bigger house and keep her kid in school.

loans.use: to buy feed for her pigs

loans.name: Angelina

texts.en:
This is Angelina, 46, a resident of Dasmarinas, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Edmundo, a security guard, and is a mother to her five children. She, together with her husband, manage their own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Angelina is a fish vendor. She buys different kinds of fish at wholesale prices and sells them by the kilo. She buys fish at the local fish port early in the morning. There are many patrons who prefer her products, since buyers are assured of her products' freshness and cleanliness. Her store is located in a temporary fish market.  Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of PHP 1,000 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 18,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more fish to be sold every day. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Angelina dreams of being able to give her all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week; there she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional stock of fish needed in her business.

loans.name: Mana Ida

texts.fr:
Mana Ida est une femme âgé(e) de 38 ans. Elle est mariée à un chauffeur et eurent ensemble 01 enfant.
Mana Ida travaille comme revendeuse d’huile de palme depuis 1989. Elle vend en gros et détail à ses clients à la maison et achète ses marchandises à l’intérieur du pays.
Mana Ida a requis son second crédit de WAGES afin d’acheter 20 bidons d’huile de palme.
Dans les prochaines années, Mana Ida voudrait avoir sa propre boutique et  exporter ses produits dans le monde. Elle dit qu’avec les profits, Elle veut aider son mari dans les charges du ménage et assurer un avenir meilleur à son enfant.
texts.en:
Mana Ida is a 38-year-old woman who is married to a driver. They have one child together. Mana Ida has been selling palm oil since 1989. She conducts her sales from her home, wholesale and retail, and she buys her merchandise within the country.

Mana Ida is seeking her second loan from WAGES to buy 20 jugs of palm oil. In the coming years, she would like to have her own shop and export her products worldwide. She plans to use the profits to help her husband with the household expenses and ensure a better future for her child.

loans.use: to buy palm oil for resale

loans.name: San Valentin Group

texts.es:
San Valentin es de la ciudad de Ygatimi, está integrado por 10 mujeres quienes entusiasmadas se unieron al a formar el grupo, pues vieron en el programa de la fundación una gran oportunidad de progresar y salir adelante con sus metas y objetivos. Actualmente se encuentran en el segundo ciclo, donde todas ponen su mejor esfuerzo para seguir.
Una de esas mujeres trabajadoras es la señora Eulalia, quien se dedica a la cría de animales. Comenta que este trabajo es un poco duro, pues implica un gran esfuerzo físico, pero dice que gracias a la ayuda de su familia puede sobrellevarlo. Gracias a este trabajo ella puede ayudar a su familia y generar los ingresos necesarios para poder salir adelante.
Ella solicita el crédito para la compra de cerdos pequeños, con lo cual podrá seguir produciendo para ayudar a su familia.
texts.en:
The San Valentin group is from the city of Ygatimi. It is made up of 10 women who are very happy to have united to form the group. They see the Fundacion's program as a great opportunity to progress and get ahead with their goals and objectives. They are now in their second cycle, and they are all doing their best to get ahead.
Eulalia is one if these hard-working women. She raises animals. She says that this work is a bit hard, because it requires a lot of physical activity, but she says that she is able to get through it thanks to her family's help. Thanks to this work, she is able to help her family and generate the necessary income to get ahead.
She is requesting this loan for the purchase of small pigs. This will allow her to keep working to help her family.

loans.use: to buy small pigs to raise.

loans.name: Adelaida

texts.en:
This is Adelaida, 51, a resident of Dasmarinas, Cavite, Philippines. She is married to Genaro, an employee, and father to her three children. She, together with her husband and children, manage their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses. 
 
Adelaida is a rice dealer. She earns income by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the kilo. Aside from the rice, she also earns money by selling fruits. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 800 in sales every day.

To help her continue operation of her business, she is requesting a PHP 38,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy fruits and sacks of rice for her business. She expects a boost in her income as she expands her business. 

Adelaida hopes to be able to expand soon, just as she hopes to give her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week; there she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional stock of rice and fruit needed in her business.

loans.name: Chheng

texts.en:
Mrs. Chheng is 52 years old and a villager who has been residing in Prey Chor district, Kompong Cham province. She works together with her husband on her inherited farmland, and is experienced at cultivating rice crops. Together, this couple is able to earn approximately $3.00 per day through this business.

She has four children, three of whom are single and live together with her in the province. She will add the loan of $500 to her saved funds so she can fix her present house partially and rebuild a bigger room for her two daughters. 

This is Mrs. Chheng's first loan from Kiva and she feels confident she will not make a late payment on any of this loan.

loans.use: to fix her present house partially and rebuild a bigger room for her two daughters.

loans.name: Mediko

texts.en:
Mediko is from the village of Norio, East Georgia. She is 67 years old and lives with her family: her husband, Guram, and their 43-year-old son and daughter in law. 

Mediko and Guram are retired and they are running a small dairy farm for the family. This is the main source of income for them. The family owns two milk cows. Mediko produces cheese and yogurt and sells them in Tbilisi (capital city of the country). Their son works in the village. He works on various seasonal agricultural jobs. The total average monthly income of the family is 350 Laris. 

Mediko requested credit for purchasing an additional milk cow. They will be able to increase production and sales of dairy products by 50%. It will have a positive impact on the income of the family. Mediko plans to use the increase in income for purchasing needed household goods, in order to improve the living conditions of the family.

loans.use: to purchase a milk cow.

loans.name: Sadullo

texts.ru: Садулло женат, прекрасный отец пятерых детей. Старший сын на заработках в России. У него трудолюбивая семья. Жена работает техничкой в школе. Они живут за счет прибыли полученной от купли продажи скота и мяса. Садулло, кроме того еще и мясник. Это ремесло перешло к нему от его отца. Он хочет получить займ на приобретение несколько голов крупного рогатого скота в размере 5000 сомони. Он заранее благодарен тем кто ему протянет руку помощи. Спасибо!
texts.en: Sadullo is married and is a beautiful father of five children.  His oldest son is working in Russia.  Sadullo has a hardworking family.  His wife works as a janitor at a school.  They make a living from the profit received from buying and selling livestock and meat.  Sadullo is also a butcher.  He inherited this trade from his father.  Sadullo wants to obtain a loan in the sum of 5000 somoni to buy several heads of cattle.  He is grateful in advance to all those, who extend a helping hand to him.  Thank you!

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen is a 36-year-old married man with six children. The family lives in a semi-permanent house in Fort Portal, Uganda. His family dream is to educate his children and look after his family very well. 

He started as a farmer and later began a motorcycle transportation business, a service he has offered for ten years. However, he has faced a challenge of mechanical breakdowns due to the poor roads and the rainy season. In spite of this, Stephen has managed to make some income to sustain his family. He needs the loan to buy another motorcycle for his transport business.

loans.use: to buy another motorcycle for his transport business.

loans.name: El Progreso Group

texts.es:
En un barrio humilde denominado Constitución de la ciudad de Caaguazú, se formo un grupo con 16 señoras trabajadoras, con deseo de superación para ellas y sus familias. Ellas saben lo que significa el trabajo diario, para sustentar a la familia y Gracias al apoyo de la Fundación Paraguaya pueden seguir luchando para dar a sus familias un sustento digno.
La señora Maria, se dedica a la venta de verduras. Dice que empieza a trabajar desde muy tempranas horas de la mañana que es cuando va a buscar productos frescos para ofrecer a sus clientes. Ella comenta que tiene muchas ventas, pues ya tiene una clientela fiel que siempre acuden a ella para surtirse. Por medio de su esfuerzo ha logrado ayudar a su familia y así salir adelante.
Ella solicita el crédito para la compra de tomates, locotes, cebollas, papas y demás tipos de verduras con lo cual podrá abastecerse y ofrecer más variedad a sus clientes. Agradece a la fundación por esta oportunidad que les da.
texts.en:
In a humble neighbourhood called Constitución, in the city of Caaguazú, there is a group of 16 hard-working woman who have a desire to get themselves and their families ahead. They know what it means to work hard every day in order to support their families. Thanks to the support of the Fundacion Paraguaya, they are able to keep fighting to give their families the best.
Mrs. Maria sells vegetables. She says that she starts working very early in the morning, going to look for fresh produce to sell. She tells us that she has good sales, since she has a loyal customer base who always turn to her for their needs. Thanks to her hard work, she has been able to help her family and get ahead.
She is requesting this loan for the purchase of tomatoes, green peppers, onions, potatoes, and other kinds of vegetables. This will allow her to stock up and offer her customers greater variety. She thanks the Fundacion for the opportunity that they are offering her group.

loans.use: to buy tomatoes, green peppers, onions, potatoes, and other vegetables.

loans.name: Adoracion

texts.en:
Adoracion is 59 years old, widowed, and has two children.  She lives in Pasay City, Philippines. Together with her children, she manages their household while operating her general store. At this time, she is working hard to provide income for their everyday expenses.  

Adoracion's store is basically a small convenience store, which sells groceries, toiletries, and beverages. She earns money by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling them by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns approximately 1,000 PHP in sales a day.

Adoracion is requesting a loan for 50,000 PHP to help her continue operation of her business. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands. 

Adoracion hopes to give all her children a good future through all her hard work. She meets weekly with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work and study the word of God.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to purchase grocery items and other products.

loans.name: Rosemary's Group

texts.en:
Rosemary's group is comprised of three hard-working women. Rosemary is 16 years old and lives in the town of Kasese in the Fort Portal region of Uganda. For the past three years, Rosemary has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells food and household goods to local customers. 

To help expand her business, Rosemary has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more food items for resale, and will help Rosemary to generate greater profits and pay for her family's medical expenses. Rosemary hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a plot of land and build a house. 

Rosemary is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Rosemary's future prospects by helping her to learn how to save money.

loans.use: to purchase more food items for resale

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy pesticides, seeds,and livestock to raise.

loans.name: Robina's Group

texts.en:
Robina is the mother of a 2 year-old daughter. Her husband is a cobbler and makes shoes, while she supports him by sewing clothes for her neighboring clients.
