Mahammad chose a very profitable business, and the products he sells in the market are in high demand. He would like to expand his business and purchase more animals. For this purpose he applied for a loan of 1,000 AZN. He will use this loan in order to purchase five sheep and two baby calves.

loans.use: to purchase sheep and calves.

loans.name: Efua

texts.en:
Efua is married to a farmer and has three children  Efua is a fishmonger and also sells kenkey (fermented corn dough wrapped in corn or banana leaves) at Kwahinkrom.  Efua uses her income to provide for the family. 

Efua is requesting a loan to purchase fish and maize.  With the new profits, Efua plans to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase fish and maize.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is a 35 year old married woman. She has four children between the ages of 3 and 12 years, three of them are in school. 

Rose has had a business of selling charcoal in Yei, South Sudan for one and a half years. Rose requested this loan through BRAC south Sudan to purchase charcoal. She says that the extra income from this loan will help her to pay the school fees for her children.

loans.use: to purchase charcoal to sell.

loans.name: Rhoda

texts.en:
Rhoda is a mother of three children, aged between 15 and 20 years, with the last two still attending schooling. She has been in farming for 5 years with her farm products of milk, eggs and maize being sold to the local market. Her family fully relies on farming for their daily upkeep.

Rhoda has requested for a loan of 61,200 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. She is optimistic that her dairy business will make better returns to meet her family's needs, like the education of her children. She also wants to buy a cereals grinding machine to process her maize into flour and to retail as a finished product. She says animal diseases remain a farmer's major challenge in the area.

loans.use: to purchase a dairy cow and poultry birds.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy maize and other food items to sell.

loans.name: Scovia's Group

texts.en:
Scovia's group is comprised of five hard working women. Scovia is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kachwamba, in the Fort Portal region of Uganda. For the past four years, Scovia has been working hard to manage her shop, which sells clothes. 

To help expand her business, Scovia has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more bundles of clothes for resale and will help Scovia to generate greater profits and improve her family's standard of living. Scovia hopes that, in the future, she will be able to buy a plot of land and build a house. 

Scovia is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Scovia's future prospects by helping her to learn what financial products are available to her.

loans.use: to purchase more bundles of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Jonathan

texts.en:
At the age of 18, Jonathan learned to manage a rice farming business with his parents. When he got married, he managed his own rice farming business. Now Jonathan is 38 and has three children who are going to school. He desires to send his children on through school and that they will hold a degree someday. 

Jonathan could not afford to finance both the daily allowances for his children and his farm as well. He decided to request a loan of P35,000 to buy seeds, fertilizers and herbicides that he will use in farming. 

In the future, Jonathan would like to see his children as professionals someday through the profit he gained from farming. He will be grateful to get the loan.

loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilizers and herbicides that he will use in farming.

loans.name: Aba

texts.en: Aba is a fishmonger at Kwahinkrom. She is married to a sanitary worker and has 7 dependents.  Aba has been selling fish for 20 years now. She assists her husband in providing for their children. Aba will use her loan to buy more fish to sell. She will expand her business with the profits she makes.

loans.use: buy more fish to sell.

loans.name: Kibisi Farmers Group

texts.en:
Salome is the facilitator of the Kibisi Farmers group. Her group joined Kiva partner One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.
Salome takes care of seven children at home. She joined One Acre Fund to grow enough to feed the family and produce enough surplus to sell. In the recent 2011 season, Salome had a very good maize yield harvesting 9 bags on 0.5 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Salome was only able to harvest 3.5 bags of maize on 0.5 acre of land.
With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Salome and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit, and insurance.
With income from maize sales, Salome will educate her children. In 2012, the members of Kibisi Farmers group will each plant maize plots between 0.5 and 1 acre.
In the photograph above, Salome is pictured with her group members.

loans.use: to source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Felistus Mawea

texts.en:
Felistus is married and  has four children. She operates a restaurant where she serves food and snacks. She has been involved in this business for six years. Her business is located in Mwingi shopping center in Thika. 

Felistus is requesting a loan for 24,000 KES, which she will use to buy wheat flour, sugar, and cooking fat. She describes her biggest business challenge to be the lack of milk in the area. Her business goal is to run another restaurant in Kyulungwa shopping center in Thika within five years.

loans.use: to purchase wheat flour, sugar, and cooking fat

loans.name: Adjoa

texts.en:
Adjoa is married and has four children. She is a fishmonger and also sells cooked rice and stew, which she has been doing for 15 years.  She assists her husband in paying utility bills.  

Adjoa is requesting a loan to purchase fish and rice in bulk. Adjoa will use her new profits to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase fish and rice in bulk.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is married to a farmer and has three children.  She sells soap and maize at Kwahinkrom, which she has been doing for 10 years. Lucy assists her husband in providing for their family. 

Lucy is requesting a loan to purchase boxes of soup and maize. She plans to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase boxes of soup and maize.

loans.name: Caren Chepkirui

texts.en:
Caren is a 29-year-old married woman. She has two children aged 10 and 12. She describes herself as a focused woman. 
Caren operates a dressmaking shop where she sells and repairs clothes. She has been involved in this business for five years and employs one staff member. Her business is located in Mauche shopping center in Nakuru town. 
Caren describes her biggest business challenge to be obtaining materials. She will use her loan of 20,000 KES to buy three rolls of material and a sewing machine. Her business goal is to expand her store within five years.

loans.use: to buy a sewing machine and three rolls of material.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase construction supplies.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy beans, peas, maize, and wheat flour.

loans.name: Kimwai Sisimuka A Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Kimwai Sisimuka A Group in Western Kenya! This  group joined Kiva partner One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.
Gilbert is the facilitator of the Kimwai Sisimuka A Group. He takes care of four children at home. He joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Gilbert had an excellent maize yield harvesting 37 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Gilbert was only able to harvest 8 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.
With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Gilbert and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit, and insurance.
With income from maize sales, Gilbert will educate his children, ensure food security, and invest in livestock rearing. In 2012, the members of Kimwai Sisimuka A group will each plant between half and 1 acre of maize.

loans.use: to source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Yunise

texts.en:
Yunise is a 38-year-old married woman who has three children aged between 5 and 15. She has run a business selling charcoal in Yei, South Sudan for two years.
Yunise has requested this loan through Kiva partner BRAC South Sudan to purchase charcoal for resale. She will use her extra income to pay school fees in the future.

loans.use: to purchase charcoal for resale.

loans.name: David Ngethe

texts.en:
David is a 29-year-old single man. He describes himself as ambitious and patient. He operates a retail store where he sells shoes. David has been involved in this business for two years. 
David describes his biggest business challenge to be inadequate funds to add to his stock of shoes. He will use his loan of 20,000 KES to buy two bales of shoes each worth 10,000 KES. His business goal is to be a major supplier of shoes in Nakuru town and its environs within five years.

loans.use: to buy two bales of shoes each worth 10,000 KES.

loans.name: Badri

texts.en:
Badri is a farmer from the village of Boriti. He is 32 years old and lives with his family: his wife – Ia, three daughters, and parents. His elder children go to school. Badri and Ia work in a local restaurant. Badri works as a waiter and Ia is a cook. Along with their main jobs, Badri and Ia are leading the family agricultural business. They have 200 vines and sell harvested grapes at a local market. Also the family grows various vegetables on the 1 hectare of land they own, and they sell the harvested vegetables at a local market as well. The family's total average monthly income is 600 Laris. 

Badri has requested a loan to purchase a milk cow. The family will produce cheese and sell it at a local market. Their income will increase, and they will improve their living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase a milk cow

loans.name: Zein Al Abidine

texts.en:
Zien Al Abidine is a 35-year-old married man and father of three children. He has worked in construction for 16 years, specializing in electrical work. He is a man of good reputation and has developed his business through good communication with people and contractors.
Zein Al Abidine is requesting his first loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua in order to replace his tools, such as the compressor, and many other electrical tools that are helpful in decreasing working time. He hopes he can expand his business and open a special construction services business with professional employees to reply to customers' needs.

loans.use: to replace his construction tools and machines.

loans.name: Bridget's Group

texts.en:
Bridget's group is comprised of four hard-working women. Bridget is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kachwamba in the Fort Portal region of Uganda. For the past two years, Bridget has been working hard to manage her shop, which sells clothes. 

To help expand her business, Bridget has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more bundles of clothes and other goods for resale, and it will help Bridget to generate greater profits and improve her family's standard of living. Bridget hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a plot of land and build a house. 

Bridget is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Bridget's future prospects by helping her to learn how to save and budget money.

loans.use: to purchase more bundles of clothes and other goods for resale

loans.name: Njete B Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Njete B Group in Western Kenya! This group joined Kiva partner One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.
Winnrose is the facilitator of the Njete B Group. She takes care of six children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Winnrose had an excellent maize yield harvesting 8 bags on half an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Winnrose was only able to harvest 2 bags of maize on half an acre of land.
With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Winnrose and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit, and insurance.
With income from maize sales, Winnrose will pay for major annual expenses, such as school fees for the children. In 2012, the members of Njete B Group will each plant between half and 1 acre of maize.
The photograph shows members of Njete B Group, with the Field Officer on the far left.

loans.use: to source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Kipngeno Bett

texts.en: Kipngeno is a 39-year-old married man. He has four children aged between nine and fifteen. He describes himself as ambitious, determined, and focused. He operates a retail store where he sells fuel. He has been involved in this business for ten years. His business is located in Mauche shopping center in Nakuru town. He describes his biggest business challenge to be inadequate capital to buy fuel. Kipngeno will use his loan of 20,000 KES to buy fuel. His business goal is to run a petrol station at Mauche shopping center within five years.

loans.use: to buy 50 liters of petrol, 30 liters of diesel, and 20 liters of kerosene.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy cloth and to cultivate land.

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James is 41 years old and is a mixed crop farmer. He is married to Eunice who is a business lady. They are blessed with two children aged 4 and 2 years old respectively. 

James has been in the farming business for the past three years with a monthly income of KES 25,000 which he uses to support his family. He is applying for his first loan term with KADET after having successfully repaid previous loans. 

James will use the loan amount to buy seedling and fertilizer for his farm. With the anticipated profits from the business he will buy a dairy cow. His hopes and dreams are to buy a commercial plot, educate his children up to university level and improve the living standard of the family.

loans.use: To buy seedling and fertilizer for his farm.

loans.name: Abini Group

texts.en:
Ben is the facilitator of the Abini group. Ben and his group joined Kiva partner One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.
Ben takes care of six children at home. He joined One Acre Fund due to One Acre Fund’s best prices and affordable loan repayments. In the recent 2011 season, Ben had a very good maize yield harvesting 6 bags on half an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Ben was only able to harvest 2 bags of maize on half an acre of land.
With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Ben and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit, and insurance.
With income from maize sales, Ben will educate his children, build a house, and invest in livestock rearing. In 2012, the members of Abini group will each plant maize plots between half and 1 acre of land.

loans.use: to source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a 23-year-old married woman. She has two children between the ages of 1 and 3.  One child is in school. She has had a business for a year selling food from a stall in Yei, South Sudan.

Mary requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase cassava flour and simsim (sesame seed) to sell. She will use the extra income she gets as a result of this loan to build a house in the future.

loans.use: to purchase cassava flour and simsim (sesame seed) to sell.

loans.name: Nicholas Ogut

texts.en:
Nicholas is 47 years old, married, and has six children. He operates a manufacturing store in Nakuru where he sells cooking pans, metal boxes, and charcoal stoves. He has been involved in this business for 10 years.  

Nicholas is requesting a loan for 20,000 KES, which he will use to buy scrap metals and paint. His business goal is to run more blacksmith stores within five years. He describes his biggest business challenge to be disturbances by the city council.

loans.use: to purchase scrap metal and paint.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 30 years old, married, and has one child. She has been running a boutique shop as a primary business and farming as a secondary business for the past seven years.  Her monthly income is 13,000 KES, which she uses to support her family.

Mary is requesting her second loan from KADET LTD after repaying her previous loan successfully. Mary will use the loan to buy new clothes for her boutique. 

With the anticipated profit from the two businesses, Mary will expand her boutique. She hopes to buy another piece of land and plant tea, which will help her improve the living standard of her family.

loans.use: to purchase new clothes for her boutique.

loans.name: John

texts.en:
John is a 42-year-old mixed crop farmer who is married to Maria, who is also a farmer. They are blessed with three children. John has been in the farming business for the past two years and makes a monthly income of 6,000 KES, which he uses to support his family.
John is applying for his first loan with Kiva partner KADET after being introduced by an existing KADET client. John will use the loan to buy fertilizer and seedlings for his farm. With the anticipated profit from the business, he will educate his children. John's hopes and dreams are to buy a piece of land and build rental houses, which will help him improve his family's standard of living.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and seedlings for his farm.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy fodder.

loans.name: Basilia

texts.es:
Basilia es socia del Banco Comunal Señor D. Huanca, tiene 56 años, es madre D. 7 hijos, es socia D. Finca Peru desD. hace 1 año, anteriormente ella ya era socia D. Finca estuvo 3 años pero por problemas familiares se retiró.
Basilia tiene una Panadería en su casa, cuando hay ferias rurales va a vender su pan, gracias a los préstamos que Finca le da paga los gastos D. estudio D. sus hijos que están en la Universidad, le gusta las capacitaciones sobre todo el cuidado D. la familia a parte que aprenD. a ahorrar, el préstamo que solicita lo invertirá en la compra D. harina, azúcar, manteca, levaduras y pasas para hacer wawas en estas fiestas próximas. Su meta es equipar su panadería y seguir creciendo.
texts.en:
Basilia is a member of the Communal Bank “Señor D. Huanca”. She is 56 years old and the mother of seven children. Basilia has been a member of FINCA Peru for the past year. She previously was a member of FINCA for three years, but decided to leave because of family problems.

Basilia has a bakery in her home. Whenever there are rural fairs being held, she takes the opportunity to sell her bread. Thanks to the loans from FINCA, she has been able to pay for her children’s educational expenses at the university. Basilia enjoys the training seminars that focus on taking care of the family and learning how to save.

The loan she is requesting will be invested in the purchase of flour, sugar, butter, yeast, and raisins so that she can make bread dolls for the upcoming festivals. Her goal is to equip her bakery and continue growing.

loans.use: to buy flour, sugar, butter, yeast, and raisins.

loans.name: Ezekiel

texts.en:
Ezekiel is a 40-year-old businessman who is married to Beatrice, who is a farmer. They are blessed with three children aged 14, 12 and 10 years respectively. Ezekiel has been running a greengrocery business for the past 11 years and makes a monthly income of 38,000 KES, which he uses to support his family.
Ezekiel is applying for his first loan with Kiva partner KADET after being introduced by a KADET staff member. Ezekiel will use the loan to purchase green vegetables and fruits to add to his stock. With the anticipated profit from the business, he will expand the business. His hopes and dreams are to buy a plot of commercial land and build rental houses, which will help him improve his family's standard of living.

loans.use: to purchase green vegetables and fruits to add to his stock.

loans.name: Faith Wanjira

texts.en:
Faith is a 45-year-old married woman. She has three children aged between 14 and 26. She describes herself as an ambitious and aggressive woman. She operates a retail store where she sells clutches, coil springs, shafts, etc. She has been involved in this business for nine years. 
Faith describes her biggest business challenge to be inadequate funds to buy more spare parts. She will use her loan of 50,000 KES to buy coil springs, shafts, and clutches. Her business goal is to run the same kind of business in major towns, like Nairobi, within five years.

loans.use: to buy clutches, coil springs, and shafts.

loans.name: Nabunulu Group

texts.en:
Martin is the facilitator of Nabunulu group. Martin and his group joined Kiva partner One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.
Martin takes care of three children at home. He joined One Acre Fund in order to grow enough food to ensure food security for his family and due to his neighbor's experience in farming. In the recent 2011 season, Martin  had a very good maize yield harvesting 18 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Martin was only able to harvest 6 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.
With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Martin and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit, and insurance.
With income from maize sales, Martin will educate his children and invest in livestock rearing. In 2012, the members of Nabunulu group will each plant maize plots between half and 1 acre of land.
The photograph shows Martin with his group members. The field officer is standing on the far left.

loans.use: to source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more food items like sorghum, maize, and cassava

loans.name: Joice

texts.en:
Joice is a 35-year-old married woman. She has no children. She has had a business selling fish in Yei, South Sudan, for two and a half years. 

Joice has requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase fish for sale. She will use the extra income to build a concrete house in the future.

loans.use: to purchase fish for sale.

loans.name: Ayme

texts.es: Ayme es socia del Banco Comunal Señor de Huanca, tiene 31 años, es madre de 1 hijo, esta en Finca hace 3 años, se dedica a la venta de tortas de queque, con los préstamos que Finca le dió logró comprar insumos en grandes cantidades tales como harina, azúcar, mantequilla, manjar, huevo, le gusta mucho las capacitaciones porque le enseña a ser responsables, a como invertir su dinero y a dirigir su negocio, a valorarse como mujer y valorar a su familia. El préstamo que solicita lo invertirá en la compra de harina, azúcar, mantequilla y huevos. Su meta es llegar a elaborar tortas variadas hasta lograr que su negocio crezca.
texts.en:
Ayme is a member of the Communal Bank “Señor de Huanca”. She is 31 years old and the mother of one child. She has been with FINCA for three years. Ayme sells cakes and cupcakes. With the loans that FINCA has provided, she has been able to buy supplies in large quantities such as flour, sugar, butter, caramel, and eggs. Ayme greatly enjoys the training seminars because they have taught her how to be responsible, invest and manage her money, and value her family and being a woman.

The loan she is requesting will be used to buy flour, sugar, butter, and eggs. Her goal is to make various cakes so that her business will grow.

loans.use: to buy flour, sugar, butter, and eggs.

loans.name: Cristhian

texts.es: el señor  Cristhian por incentivo de sus padres abrió su foto estudio hace varios años atrás es soltero no tiene hijos y vive en la casa de sus papas durante todo este tiempo demostró ser muy trabajador y responsable ayudando en la economía de su familia y dando ejemplo a sus hermanos menores  por las noches estudia photoshop en un instituto esto le ayuda mucho en su trabajo de revelado y ediciones de fotos su estudio fotográfico se encuentra ubicado cerca de la plaza principal de sacaba el préstamo lo invertirá en la compra de una cámara filmadora profesional que le servirá para renovarse y realizar mejores trabajos porque tiene mucha demanda de clientes por sus excelentes trabajos y también por estas fiestas de fin de año.
texts.en:
Sr. Cristhian was encouraged by his parents to open his photo studio several years ago. He is single, has no children, and lives at the home of his parents. Throughout this time, he has demonstrated that he is extremely hardworking and responsible in helping with the family finances. He also sets an example for his younger siblings. At night, he studies Photoshop at an institute which has helped him in his work of developing and editing photos in his studio. His business is located near the main square.

The loan he is receiving will be invested in the purchase of a professional video camera, which will help him obtain and perform better jobs because there is great demand among his customers for his excellent work. This will also enable him to be equipped for the year-end parties.

loans.use: to buy a professional video camera.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase large and small cattle.

loans.name: Marumba Bulala Group

texts.en:
Damascus is the facilitator of the Marumba Bulala group. Damascus and his group joined Kiva partner One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.
Damascus takes care of six children at home. He joined One Acre Fund due to One Acre Fund’s best prices and in order to ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Damascus had an excellent maize yield harvesting 12.5 bags on 0.5 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund,  Damascus was only able to harvest 3 bags of maize on 0.5 acre of land.
With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Damascus and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit, and insurance.
With income from maize sales, Damascus will educate his children and invest in livestock rearing. In 2012, the members of Marumba Bulala group will each plant maize plots between 0.5 and 1 acre of land.

loans.use: to source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah lives in Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has 6 children, all of whom are in school.  She also takes care of additional family members (a brother). Sarah has a business selling charcoal.  She has been in this business for 10 years, and she works 7 days a week. Sarah sells her products at the market, as retail. 

Sarah has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of charcoal. The main business challenges for Sarah include transportation and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start selling only wholesale and to own a delivery van. 

Sarah lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity and piped water.  Her major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.

loans.use: to buy more bags of charcoal.

loans.name: Yackeline

texts.es:
Yackeline de 25 años vive en la linda capital de Colombia, Bogotá, con su cónyuge y su pequeño hijo de 1 año de edad. Desde hace 3 años ella inició un negocio con la ayuda de su cuñada en el cual confecciona y comercializan ropa especialmente en tela de jeans. 

En su negocio maneja un sistema donde ella diseña y corta pantalones para damas y los envía a una microempresa satélite, para que sean confeccionados y comercializados en eventos de comercialización como “el madrugón”, que tiene lugar los días miércoles y sábados. 

Su mayor sueño es tener su propia casa y lograr incorporar a su negocio todo el proceso de la confección. En la actualidad está aplicando a su primer financiamiento con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, mediante el cual comprará materia prima como telas hilos e hilazas para la fabricación de jeans para la temporada de final de año, en el cual las ventas se incrementan y ella debe aprovechar para ganar un buen dinero. Esta es la razón por la cual acude a su credikiva.
texts.en:
Jackeline is 25 years old and lives in the beautiful capital of Colombia, Bogotá, with her spouse and small 1-year old son.  She started a business three years ago, with the help of her mother-in-law, making clothing from jeans fabric.

The system she uses in her business is that she designs and cuts jeans for women, then sends them to a satellite enterprise to be produced.  She offers them at various merchandising events such as at ““El Madrugón”, which takes place at dawn on Wednesdays and Saturdays.

Her biggest dreams are to have her own house and to manage to incorporate all levels of manufacturing into her business.  Currently, she is applying for her first loan through Fundación Mario Santo Domingo.  She plans to buy raw materials such as fabrics, threads and yarns for making jeans for the holiday season.  

This is a time when demand and sales are higher, and she must take advantage of the opportunity to make good money.  This is the reason why she appeals for Kiva credit.

loans.use: buy more raw materials such as fabrics, threads and yarns for manufacturing jeans.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more items like maize flour, cassava flour, sorghum and milllet.

loans.name: Madina

texts.en:
Madina lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has six children, all of whom are in school. She also takes care of additional family members (her father and mother). Madina lives in a home that she owns; she has access to electricity but doesn't have access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.   
Madina has a business selling bananas. She has been in this business for one year, and works 7 days per week. Madina sells her products at the market, by means of retail. She has requested a loan of 700,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner MCDT SACCO. She will use her loan to buy more bunches of bananas. The main business challenges for Madina include transportation and the increasing prices of commodities in Uganda. 
Her goals and aspirations for her business are to become a wholesaler and own a delivery van.

loans.use: to buy more bunches of bananas.

loans.name: Tumaini Group

texts.en:
Moses is the facilitator of the Tumaini group. Moses and his group joined Kiva partner One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.
Moses takes care of seven children at home. He joined One Acre Fund due to One Acre Fund’s best prices and in order to ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Moses had an excellent maize yield harvesting 10 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Moses was only able to harvest 3 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.
With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Moses and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit, and insurance.
With income from maize sales, Moses will educate his children and invest in livestock rearing. In 2012, the members of Tumaini group will each plant maize plots between half and 1 acre of land.
In the photograph above, Moses is pictured with his group members. The person standing on the far left is the field officer.

loans.use: to source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is a 24-year-old married woman with two children aged one and four, one of whom is in school. She has run a business selling clothes in Yei, South Sudan, for four years.
Jane has requested this loan through Kiva partner BRAC South Sudan to purchase clothes. She will use her extra income from this loan to build a house in the future.

loans.use: to purchase clothes for resale.

loans.name: Koba

texts.en:
Koba is a farmer from the village of Koreti. He is 47 years old and lives with his large family: his wife (Nato), four children (15, 13, 11 and 8 years old), father and aunt. All his children go to school. Koba’s father and aunt are retired. 
Koba runs the family's agricultural business. They have a small dairy farm with three milk cows and three calves. Koba's wife sells the dairy products at the local market. Koba and his family also own 0.8 hectare of land, where they grow various vegetables. Selling harvested vegetables is another source of income for the family. The family's total average monthly income is 350 GEL. 
Koba has requested credit to purchase a plot of land. The family will be able to sow more vegetables and produce more harvest, with the consequence that the family's income will increase. Koba plans to reinvest his increased income in the family business in order to make it more profitable.

loans.use: to purchase agricultural land.

loans.name: Umoja A Group

texts.en:
Edward is the facilitator of the Umoja A group. Edward and his group joined Kiva partner One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.
Edward takes care of five children at home. He joined One Acre Fund to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds. In the recent 2011 season, Edward had a very good maize yield harvesting 12.5 bags on 0.5 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Edward was only able to harvest 6.5 bags of maize on 0.5 acre of land.
With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Edward and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit, and insurance.
With income from maize sales, Edward will educate his children and invest in livestock rearing. In 2012, the members of Umoja A group will each plant maize plots between 0.5 and 1 acre of land.
In the photograph above, Edward is pictured with his group members.

loans.use: to source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to stock up on winter goods.

loans.name: Jackelinne Benita

texts.es: La señora Jackelinne vive junto a su esposo Rubén en la zona de Pampahasi alto, tienen dos hijos en edad escolar. Jackelinne se dedica a atender un pequeño negocio de licorería que esta instalado en el mismo domicilio donde viven. El esposo de ella trabaja como diseñador grafico en una empresa de diseño que queda en la zona de Villa Copacabana, Jackelinne trabaja con la institución desde hace varios años y siempre ha demostrado ser muy puntual y responsable con el pago de sus cuotas. Ahora que se acercan las fiestas de fin de año, Jackelinne solicita el préstamo para la compra de otras bebidas como refrescos por mayor para incrementar su capital antes que se eleven los precios por estas fiestas de fin de año.
texts.en:
Sra. Jackelinne lives with her husband Rubén in the District of Pampahasi Alto. They have two children in school. Jackelinne manages a small liquor store located in her home. Her husband works as a graphic designer for a printing company in the District of Villa Copacabana.

Jackelinne has worked with Emprender for several years and has always demonstrated her promptness and responsibility when making her payments. Now that the year-end festivities are approaching, Jackelinne is requesting a loan to buy other beverages, such as soft drinks in bulk, so that she can acquire more inventory before prices increase as a result of the holiday parties.

loans.use: to buy soft drinks in bulk.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase fruits.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase a dairy cow.

loans.name: Peace Maker Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Peace Maker Group in Western Kenya! This  group joined Kiva partner One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.
Amina is the facilitator of the Peace Maker group. She takes care of six children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Amina had an excellent maize yield harvesting 10 bags on half an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Amina was only able to harvest 4 bags of maize on half an acre of land.
With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Amina and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit, and insurance.
With income from maize sales, Amina will educate her children and invest in livestock rearing. In 2012, the members of Peace Maker group will each plant between half and 1 acre of maize.

loans.use: to source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more food items like cassava flour and maize flour.

loans.name: Aba

texts.en:
Aba is married to a farmer and has 5 dependants. She sells maize dough and rice porridge at Dompoase. She has been selling maize for 15 years.  Aba supports her husband to pay the school fees of his children.  

She will use her loan to purchase bulk maize and rice. Aba will expand her business with her profits.

loans.use: purchase bulk maize and rice.

loans.name: Leoncia

texts.es:
Leoncia es socia del Banco Comunal Señor de Huanca, tiene 41 años, es madre de 5 hijos, es socia de Finca Peru desde hace 1 año y medio, anteriormente ella vendía anticuchos y chicha, gracias al apoyo de sus hijas ahora se dedica a la venta de abarrotes en ferias, porque su anterior negocio esta a cargo de sus hijas.
Gracias a los préstamos que ha recibido anteriormente ha podido apoyar a 2 de sus hijos a estudiar  electrónica, agradece mucho por las capacitaciones recibidas ya que aprendió ahorrar, a ser responsable y valorar a su familia. El préstamo que solicita lo invertirá en la compra de herramientas electrónicas para sus hijos. Su meta a corto plazo es comprar su terreno para podr vivir tranquila con sus hijos.
texts.en:
Leoncia is a member of the village bank Senor de Huanca. She is 41 years old and a mother of 5 children. She has been part of Finca Peru for a year and a half. Before that she was selling anticuchos [grilled beef heart] and chicha [a corn drink]. Thanks to help from her daughters, she now sells groceries at markets - her daughters took charge of the previous business.

Thanks to her prior loans she has been able to support her two of her children as they study electronics. She is very thankful for the trainings she has received because she has learned to save and be responsible and value her family. The requested loan will be invested in the purchase of electronic tools for her children. Her short-term goal is to buy land so that she can live a peaceful life with her family.

loans.use: to buy electronic tools for her children's studies.

loans.name: Leonor

texts.es:
Leonor es socia del Banco Comunal Diamantes, es socia D. FINCA Peru desD. hace 1 año y medio.
Leonor se dedica a la venta D. cereales en Ica, con los primeros préstamos que recibió aumentó su capital D. negocio y pudo comprar cereales en grandes cantidades, ella esta muy agradecida a Finca por el apoyo que le brindaron, aprendió a poder ser mejor negociante y a poder ahorrar y eso es lo que ella mas valora. El préstamo que solicita lo invertirá en la compra D. cereales. Su meta es construir su casa.
texts.en: Leonor is a member of the communal bank Diamantes and has been a member of FINCA Peru for a year and a half. Leonor sells grains in Ica. With the first loans she received she increased her working capital and bought dry grains in bulk. She is very grateful to FINCA for the support extended to her. She learned how to be a better business person and be able to save and that it is what she most values. The loan she is asking for is to purchase dry grains. Her goal is to build a house.

loans.use: to buy dry grains.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more items like sorghum, maize, dried cassava, and millet.

loans.name: Robinah

texts.en:
Robinah lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has four children, all of whom are in school. Robinah lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity but doesn't have access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.   
Robinah runs a pub. She has been in this business for ten years, and works seven days per week. Robinah sells her products from home, by means of retail. She has requested a loan of 300,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more crates of beer and soda. Robinah also generates additional income through selling charcoal. The main business challenges for Robinah include transportation and seasonality. Her goals and aspirations for her business are to own a fully stocked pub and to educate her children up to university.

loans.use: to buy more crates of beer and soda.

loans.name: Josefa

texts.es: La señora Josefa, es una cliente que esta en su segunda secuencia D. crédito, con buena referencia crediticia, ella se dedica a la venta D. salteñas y a la atención D. su tienda D. barrio que se encuentra en el mismo domicilio cabe destacar que es D. su propiedad y este esta ubicado en la zona Alto Tacagua, en la elaboración D. salteñas la ayuda su esposo que también se dedica a la elaboración D.  helados, entre los dos se ayudan mutuamente y podemos ver que son buenos clientes siempre tratando D. pagar sus cuotas al día. El motivo D. este crédito es porque la señora desea elaborar una mayor cantidad  D. salteñas ya que encontró mas puntos D. venta y D. paso también quiere surtir su tienda debido a que se acerca fin D. año y las ventas están aumentando. Con la visita que se realizo a su domicilio y a la vez a su negocio se pueD. ver que la señora tiene mucho entusiasmo en poder expandirse en la venta D. salteñas, pero para ello necesita D. este crédito.
texts.en: Señora Josefa is a member who is in her second loan cycle, with a good credit rating. She sells salteñas (baked empanadas) and takes care of her neighbourhood store which is located in her own house. It should be noted that the house is her own property and is located in the Alto Tacagua area. Her husband helps her make the salteñas. He also makes icecream. Between the two of them, they help each other and we can see that they are good members always trying to make their repayments on time. The reason for this loan is because the lady wants to make a larger quantity of salteñas as she identified more points of sale and incidently also wants to stock her store as the end of year is approaching and sales are increasing. With the visit to her house and her business, it is evident that the lady is very enthusiastic about expanding her sales of salteñas, but needs the loan in order to do this.

loans.use: to buy flour to make baked empanadas (savoury pastries) and buy groceries to stock her neighbourhood store.

loans.name: María

texts.es:
María integrante del Banco comunal “Oportunidad” perteneciente a la comuna de Padre de las Casas, ciudad de Temuco.
Se dedica al rubro de comercio, específicamente vende frutas, abarrotes, bebidas, en un local que arrienda.
Se dedica a su negocio desde hace 7 años y trabaja de lunes a sábado.
Su mercadería la compra en supermercados mayoristas, distribuidoras, proveedores y en la feria compra las frutas. 
Con el crédito comprará frutas de temporada, entre sandias, kiwis, mandarinas, manzanas, uvas y melones.
Las metas en su negocio son instalarse con un local establecido en su propia casa, ya que el gasto de arriendo la limita para invertir en más mercadería y nuevas maquinarias.
Comenta que la temporada de más alta demanda, son los meses de primavera verano, ya que vende frutas de temporada.
Su marido e hijo la ayudan en la atención de clientes en su negocio, por lo que se siente apoyada.
Además comenzará a participar en gimnasia de relajación para desestresarse de las labores domesticas.
María vive junto a su marido y sus tres hijos de 22, 20 y 18 años de edad, quienes estudian y trabajan. El sueño de ella es adquirir su casa propia, para esto ya postuló al subsidio habitacional, puesto que participa de un comité para la vivienda. 
Ella está muy contenta y agradecida de la oportunidad que le ha brindado Fondo esperanza para invertir en su negocio. Además se siente muy cómoda con el grupo que comparte, ya que son muy unidos y responsables. 
Respecto a las capacitaciones, estas le han servido para perfeccionarse en la administración y contabilidad de su negocio, ya que ha implementado nuevas estrategias.
Padre Las Casas es una comuna del sur de Chile, cercana a la ciudad de Temuco, región de la Araucanía.  Su nombre le fue dado en honor al sacerdote español Bartolomé de Las Casas, quien fue un defensor de los indígenas durante la conquista de América. Destaca una numerosa población mapuche en esta comuna. Basa su economía en la agroindustria y servicios comerciales.
texts.en:
María is a member of  the communal bank "Oportunidad" which belongs to the municipality of Padre de las Casas, in the city of Temuco. She sells fruit, groceries, drinks in leased premises. She has been running her business for 7 years and works Monday through Saturday. She buys her merchandise from wholesale supermarkets, distibutors and suppliers and her fruit in the street market. With the loan she will buy seasonal fruit such as watermelons, kiwis, mandarin oranges, apples, grapes and melons. Her business goals are to establish the store in her own house as the rent she pays limits her ability to invest in more merchandise and new equipment. She says that the seasons with the highest demand are spring and summer as she sells seasonal fruit. Her husband and child help her serve customers for which she feels supported. In addition she will begin a relaxation exercise class to destress from her household activities.

María lives with her husband and 3 children of 22, 20 and 18 years of age, who study and work. Her dream is to buy her own house and to this end she has already applied for a housing subsidy as she is a member of a housing committee. She is very happy and grateful for the opportunity the Fondo has extended her, giving her hope to invest in her business. She feels also very comfortable with her group as they are very unitied and responsible. With regard to the training, it has served to improve her business administration and accounting as she has implemented new strategies.
.
Padre Las Casas is a municipality in the south of Chile near the city of Temuco in the region of Araucania. It was given this name in honour of the Spanish priest Bartolomé de Las Casas who was a defender of the indigenous people during the conquest of America. The community has a large Mapuche population. Its economy is based on the agricultural industry and commercial services.

loans.use: to buy seasonal fruit such as watermelons, kiwis, mandarin oranges, apples, grapes and melons.

loans.name: Natela

texts.en:
Natela is from the village of Lakhundara. She is 61 years old, retired, and lives with her family: her husband – Rezo – and her 35-year-old son. 
Natela’s family earns a living through agricultural activities. They have two cows and a calf. Natela produces cheese and sells it at the local market. Along with the dairy farm, the family owns 0.8 hectare of land, which is used for growing vegetables. Harvested vegetables are sold at the local market as well. The family's total average monthly income is 370 GEL, which includes Natela and Rezo's monthly pensions. 
The family has decided to expand the existing dairy farm. Natela has requested credit for purchasing a milk cow. Having three milk cows, she will be able to increase production and sales of cheese by 50 per cent. The family income will increase and they will be able to spend more daily in order to improve their living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase a milk cow.

loans.name: Imani A Group

texts.en:
Wycliffe is the facilitator of the Imani A group. Wycliffe and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.
Wycliffe takes care of nine children at home. He joined One Acre Fund in order to have additional maize profits to send his children to school and to access fertilizers and hybrid seed. In the recent 2011 season, Wycliffe had a very good maize yield harvesting 20 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Wycliffe was only able to harvest 4 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.
With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Wycliffe and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit, and insurance.
With income from maize sales, Wycliffe will educate his children and invest in livestock rearing. In 2012, the members of Imani A group will each plant maize plots between half and 1 acre of land.
The photograph shows the members of the group.

loans.use: to source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy more foodstuffs for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more provisions and items for resale.

loans.name: Baraka

texts.en:
Baraka is 27 years old, married to Tabitha, and has one child. For the last two years he has done decoration, painting, and drawing, and sold African curios. He makes an income of 15,000 KES per month.
Baraka had never borrowed from any other microfinance institution (MFI) before he took his first loan with Kiva partner KADET. He has applied for his second loan after successfully repaying his previous loan well and in good time. He plans to buy paints and curios for resale. With his anticipated profits, Baraka plans to support his family, grow his business, and become financially stable in the future.

loans.use: to buy paints and curios for resale.

loans.name: Timothe

texts.fr:
Client de 50 ans, marie et père de 2 enfants dont l'age varie entre 21 et 23 ans.Après ses etudes universitaires , n'ayant pas trouve du travail, il se lance dans la vente des ustensiles en plastique tel que des séries de cuvettes, des seaux, des chaises, des bassines et des gobelets...
Il a des recettes de 50.000frs a 100.000frs par jour, par moment il va a Kinshasa pour aller s'approvisionner .

A l'octroi de ce nouveau prêt, il va renforcer son commerce et agrandir le stock de ses marchandises.Ces differents prêts  ont agrandi son capital, aujourd'hui il n'achète plus a crédit, les achats se font en gros , il a fait des épargnes considérables et a rembourser sans difficulté.

Son ambition est de d'élargir son dépôt et d'ouvrir un autre coin de vente pour satisfaire les désirs de ses clients.Il est le pilier de sa famille , soutien les etudes universitaires de ses enfants et il est très populaire dans son quartier.
texts.en:
The 50-year-old client is married and the father of two children who are 21 and 23 years old. After his university studies, when he couldn't find work, he went into business selling plastic kitchenware, such as washbowls, buckets, chairs, bowls and cups. His income is between 50,000 and 100,000 frs per day and at times he goes to Kinshasa to stock up. 

With this new loan, he is going to expand his business and increase his stock of merchandise. These various loans have increased his capital and today he no longer buys on credit; he purchases wholesale. He has made considerable savings and paid back his loans without any problems.

His dream is to expand his store and to open another storefront to satisfy his customers' needs. He is the pillar of his family, supporting his children's university studies, and he is very popular in his neighborhood.

loans.use: To buy bowls, baskets, tables, basins, etc.

loans.name: Naana

texts.en: Naana sells wakye (a spiced rice and bean dish), rice, and stew at Kwahinkrom. She has been selling wakye and rice for the past ten years now. Naana is married to a farmer and has four children. She assists her husband in paying their children’s school fees. Her loan will be used to purchase bags of rice, beans, and fish. Naana will use her new profits to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase bags of rice, beans, and fish.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is a 38-year-old married woman. She has a daughter who is six years old. Grace describes herself as energetic, patient, determined, and trustworthy. 
Grace operates a chicken sales business. She has been involved in this business for eight years. Her business is located in Nakuru. She describes her biggest business challenge to be the increased transportation costs for the chickens. She will use her loan of 50,000 KES to buy food for the chickens and set up a room for them. Her business goal is to expand her business internationally and run shops within five years.

loans.use: to set up a room for the chickens and buy food for them.

loans.name: Amoka

texts.en: Amoka is a kenkey (fermented corn dough wrapped in corn or banana leaves) seller and a fishmonger at Kwahinkrom. She has been in this business for three years now. She is married to a mason and has four children. She assists her husband in providing for their children. Amoka will use her loan to purchase maize and fish in bulk. With her new profits, she plans to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase maize and fish in bulk.

loans.name: Regina

texts.en:
Regina is a 35-year-old businesswoman who lives in Juba. She is married and has five children between the ages of 16 years old and 11 months.  Four of them go to school. 

Regina runs a food store business, and she has been in the business for one year. She has no employees. Regina heard about Finance Sudan through advertising done at her market. She is taking out a loan of 600 SDG to purchase more food items like Irish potatoes, onions, and spices. In addition to this business, Regina has no other source of income. 

In five years' time, Regina would like to hope for growth in the business and at least sell in a shop. Her major challenges include high household expenses.   

Regina says that she is happy about Finance Sudan’s support in South Sudan.

loans.use: to purchase more food items like Irish potatoes, onions, and spices.

loans.name: Joyce Bugutsa

texts.en:
Joyce is a 30-year-old married woman. She has four children with ages ranging from 2 years to 11. She describes herself as highly motivated and generous. She operates a beauty salon where she provides hair dressing services like blow drying, plaiting, etc. She has been involved in this business for six years. Her business is located in Nakuru. 

Joyce describes her biggest business challenge to be the increased cost of electricity, too few clients and the increased cost of hair products. She will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy hair oil. Her business goal is to expand  within five years.

loans.use: To buy hair oil and other products.

loans.name: Esi

texts.en: Esi is a single parent and has six dependents. She has been selling cloth and cosmetics at Kwahinkrom for the past 12 years now. Esi uses her income to provide for her children. She will use her loan to buy more cloth and cosmetics for sale. Esi has planned to expand her business with her new profit.

loans.use: buy more cosmetics and cloth for sale.

loans.name: Consuelo

texts.es: La socia es docente de profesion y trabaja en la comunidad de Anta y a esta actividad ella a complementado la compra y venta de ropa, la socia viaja y compra de las diferentes fabricas al por mayor ropa para damas, caballeros y niños ropa y los distribuye entre sus colegas de trabajo, amistades, y tiendas de venta de ropa; la socia esta contenta porque le ha ido muy bien el negocio y desea capitalizarse ella invertira el dinero en la compra de ropa por temporada y la distribuira en las diversas tiendas en diferentes provincias en Cusco y de este modo la socia esta creciendo economicamente, la socia desea un futuro tranquilo y que cuando se jubile siga en actividad como a ella le gusta estar y talvez poner un negocio en casa o algo que la distraiga y permite tener calidad de vida. La socia desea al prestamo para invertir en la compra la por mayor de ropa para la venta y mejorar sus ingresos economicos.
texts.en: The member is a teacher by profession and works in Anta. She has complemented this work by buying and selling clothes. The member travels and buys wholesale from different factories ladies', men's and children's clothing and then distributes them among her teaching colleagues, friends and shops that sell clothes. The member is happy because her business is doing well and she wants to capitalize it. She will invest the money in buying seasonal clothes and distributing them to various shops in the different provinces of Cusco. In this way the member is growing economically. The member wishes for a peaceful future and that she remain active when she retires as she likes to be, and perhaps set up a business at home or something to keep her busy and allow her to have a good quality of life. The member wants the loan to purchase wholesale clothes to sell and improve her income.

loans.use: to buy clothes wholesale to sell and improve her income.

loans.name: Jembe Shg Bidii Group

texts.en:
David is the facilitator of the Jembe SHG Bidii group. David and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

David takes care of three children at home. He joined One Acre Fund due to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds. In the recent 2011 season, David had a good maize yield, harvesting 7 bags on ½ an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund,  David was only able to harvest 4 bags of maize on ½  acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to David and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, David will educate his children and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Jembe SHG Bidii group will each plant maize plots of between ½ and 1 acre of land.

In the photograph above, David is pictured with his group members and the field officer on the far left.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Martin Njuguna

texts.en: Martin is a 25-year-old married man. He describes himself as vigilant. He operates a transportation service where he provides "tuk tuk" transport services. He has been involved in this business for four years. His business is located in Nakuru. He describes his biggest business challenge to be the traffic police disturbance. He will use the Kes 95,000 loan to buy spare parts and save for buying another "tuk tuk". His business goal is to own more "tuk tuk"s within 5 years.

loans.use: to buy spare parts and save to buy another "tuk tuk" (small transport vehicle).

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to increase her stock of clothing.

loans.name: Sylvia

texts.en:
Sylvia lives in Kampala, Uganda. She is married and has two children, one of whom is in school. She also takes care of additional family members. Sylvia lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity but doesn't have access to piped water. Her major monthly expenses include school fees and feeding the family.
Sylvia has a beauty salon business. She has been in this business for two years, and works seven days per week. Sylvia sells products in her shop by means of retail. She has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more boxes of cream relaxers and braids. The main business challenges for Sylvia include the increasing prices of cream relaxers and braids, and seasonality. 
Sylvia's goals and aspirations are to own a fully stocked bridal salon and build her own house.

loans.use: to buy more boxes of cream relaxers and braids.

loans.name: Sandra Milena

texts.es:
La señora Sandra se dedica a la confección de ropa a terceros gracias al apoyo recibido por su padre quien la empleo en su propio taller de confección. En el taller de su padre Sandra adquiere experiencia y se capacita en esta área de la confección realizando desde hace 13 años esta labor. Sandra impulsada por sacar adelante a su hija de 11 años y a sus 31 años de edad decide independizarse utilizando sus ahorros para comprar las máquinas de confección con las que inicio su propio negocio generando actualmente 2 empleos directos en su propio taller de confección.
La señora Sandra espera comprar una maquina recubridora que le permitirá provisionarse y aumentar la producción con el fin de tener para la temporada entre enero y febrero buenos recursos económicos ahorrados, puesto que en estas fechas el trabajo disminuye.  La señora Sandra desea y espera seguir mejorando su calidad de vida y aumentar el tiempo que le dedica a su hija y a futuro tener su propia línea de ropa.
texts.en:
Sandra sews clothes for third parties thanks to the support received from her father who employed her in his own dressmaking workshop.  In her father's workshop, Sandra gained experience and trained in dressmaking, working in this job for 13 years.  Motivated by the need to provide for her 11-year-old daughter, at 31 years of age Sandra decided to start working for herself.  She used her savings to buy some dressmaking machines with which she started her own business, creating 2 direct jobs in her own dressmaking workshop.

Sandra hopes to buy a cover-stitch machine which will allow her to increase her production so that, by the time January and February come around, she will have a good amount of money saved up as this is a time of year in which her work slows down.  Sandra would like and hopes to continue improving her quality of life and to increase the amount of time that she can devote to her daughter.  In the future, she would like to have her own clothing line.

loans.use: to buy a cross-stitch machine for her dressmaking workshop

loans.name: Venney

texts.en:
Venney is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kachwamba in the Fort Portal region of Uganda. She is married and has two children, one of whom is currently in school. 
For the past three years, Venney has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells food and home supplies to local customers. To help expand her business, Venney has requested a loan of 400,000 Ugandan Shillings from Kiva partner BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more sugar, soap, and cooking oil, and will help Venney to generate greater profits and pay her children's school fees. Venney hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a plot of land and build a house. 
Venney is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Venney's future prospects by helping her learn how to save and manage her money.

loans.use: to purchase more sugar, soap, and cooking oil.

loans.name: Julius Ngethe

texts.en:
Julius is a 27-year-old married man. He has a child who is eight months old. He describes himself as hardworking. 
Julius operates a transport business providing motorcycle services. He has been involved in this business for three years. His business is located in Nakuru. He describes his biggest business challenge to be the traffic police and climate change. He will use his loan of 60,000 KES to buy a motorbike. His goal is to add more stock to his wife's tailoring business within five years.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike.

loans.name: José Eligio

texts.es:
El señor José tiene 51 años de edad, es casado con tres hijos.

Él se ha dedicado toda su vida a realizar actividades agrícolas,  y fue su papá quien le enseño este trabajo. Se desplaza largas distancias todos los días, a cuidar a su ganado para obtener ingresos para su familia. Los insumos que necesita para realizar su trabajo los adquiere en una ciudad que se encuentra a 40 kilómetros de distancia.

José solicita un préstamo para comprar de dos a tres vacas lecheras, para sacarles leche y procesarla y vender queso, de esta forma tendrá una fuente de ingresos y las alimentara de lo que él cosecha.

José desea brindarle a su familia una mejor calidad de vida, y cuidar de su papá ya que esta muy enfermo y él quiere darle todo lo que pueda mientras lo tenga a su lado.
texts.en:
José is 51 years old and is married with three children.

He has spent his whole life performing agricultural work and it was his father who taught him about this work. He travels long distances every day to care for his livestock and to earn an income for his family. He acquires the supplies he needs to complete his work in a city that is 40 kilometers away. 

José seeks a loan to buy 2-3 milk cows, to collect and process milk from and to sell cheese. This way he will have a source of income and he will feed them what he grows.

José wants to provide a better quality of life for his family and to care for his father who is very sick. He wants to give him all that he can while he has him by his side.

loans.use: to buy 2-3 milk cows

loans.name: Jane

texts.en:
Jane is a 44-year-old divorced woman. She has three children aged between 16 and 22. She describes herself as hardworking. 
Jane operates a clothes retail store. She has been involved in this business for four years. Her business is located in Nairobi central. Jane describes her biggest business challenge to be the low purchasing power of her customers. She will use her loan of 40,000 KES to buy more clothes for resale and to renovate her business stall. Her business goal is to run a boutique within five years.

loans.use: to renovate her store and add to her stock of clothes.

loans.name: Tamar

texts.en:
Tamar is a farmer from the village of Boriti, West Georgia. She is 38 years old, married to David, and has four children – three daughters (18, 17 and 5 years old) and a four-year-old son. Tamar’s mother-in-law also lives with the family. 
The family's only source of income is agriculture. They have one milk cow. Tamar produces cheese and sells it in Zestaponi (a nearby town). The family also has three pigs and sells on average 30 piglets in the village. In addition, Tamar and David grow vegetables and corn on the 0.8 hectare of land that the family own. They sell harvested vegetables and corn on Zestaponi market. Their total average monthly income is 400 GEL, which includes Tamar's mother-in-law's monthly pension. 
Tamar has requested credit for purchasing chickens. She will raise them and sell eggs as well as hens. She will also use a small part of the funds to renovate the henhouse. Tamar has experience in running a poultry farm and she will use it to set up the new business. She says that it will be profitable and the family will have more income, which will be used for improving their living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase chickens plus materials for henhouse renovation.

loans.name: José Israel

texts.es:
El señor José tiene 27 años de edad, es acompañado con dos hijos.

Él desde pequeño ha trabajado en la agricultura y actualmente es empleado de una empresa en donde realiza  reparación de carreteras, también realiza actividades agrícolas de la cual se beneficia.

Sale de su casa a las 4:00 a.m. para su trabajo y ahí pasa todo el día, el día libre lo dedica a trabajar en actividades agrícolas, ya que es un hombre que lucha por su vida y la de su familia.

José es un hombre emprendedor y hoy desea instalar una tienda en su casa, por eso el préstamo que solicita es para comprar productos como fríjol, azúcar, arroz, jabón, entre otros más y para comprar dos silos(deposito para guardar granos básicos) para almacenar la producción de maíz.

Con la inversión él tendrá seguro su maíz, para poderlo vender en otro momento en que el precio sea mejor. Con la instalación de la tienda dispondrá de otra fuente de ingresos, para su familia y su esposa se encargara de tratar con los clientes, mientras él realiza las otras actividades. Así José espera proporcionarle todo lo necesario a su familia.
texts.en:
Mr. José is 27 years old and lives with his common-law wife and two children.  He began working in agriculture from a very early age and now he is employed at a company that repairs roads.  He also carries out agricultural activities for an income.

He leaves for work at 4:00 a.m. and stays there all day.  On his free days he works in agriculture as a way of helping his family get ahead.

José is an entrepreneur who wants to set up a store in his house.  He is requesting a loan to buy products such as beans, sugar, rice, soap, etc. and to buy two silos (to keep basic grains) where he will store corn.

With the investment he will insure his corn and be able to sell it at the right time to get the best price.  The store will add extra income for his family.  His wife will attend to customers while he is involved in other activities.  José hopes that through this he will be able to give his family all they need.

loans.use: To buy products such as beans, sugar, rice, soap, etc. and to buy two silos.

loans.name: Teresia

texts.en: Teresia is single. She describes herself as optimistic. She has been running a general store for the last six years. The business is faced with the challenge of increased price of goods. She will be using the loan of Kes 20,000 to add  to her stock of household necessities. In the future, Teresia looks forward to expanding her business.

loans.use: To add to her stock of household necessities.

loans.name: Roxana Jeannette

texts.es:
La señora Roxana tiene 36 años de edad, esta acompañada no tiene hijos, pero sus padres dependen de ella. Hace varios años ella se dedica a procesar la leche y obtener queso, crema y guajada, estas las vende en las comunidades aledañas.

Roxana se levanta a las 3:00 a.m. para dirigirse, donde los ganaderos a comprar la leche, ya que es ha esta hora que ella puede comprar. Una vez que ha recolectado la leche, la procesa y el siguiente día a las 5:00 a.m. sale a vender el producto.

Roxana solicita un préstamo a Fundación Campo, para comprar una vaca lechera, para obtener más leche y elaborar más productos, para obtener mayores ingresos y ahorrar porque ya no compraría tanta leche a otras personas, sino que ella misma dispondrá de ella.

Roxana desea tener pronto un hijo y brindarle todo lo necesario. Además quiere tener una ganadería propia y procesar más leche y recibir mejores ingresos y darle una mejor vida a su familia.
texts.en:
Roxana is 36 years old and has a partner.  She has no children, but her parents are dependent upon her.  For a number of years she has been processing milk to make cheese, cream and cheese curd, which she sells in the surrounding communities.

Roxana gets up at 3am to go to the dairy farmers to buy the milk, since this is the hour when she is able to buy it.  Once she has collected the milk, she processes it and at 5am on the next day she goes out to sell her products.

Roxana requests a loan from Fundación Campo to buy a dairy cow, so that she could have more milk and make more products.  This way she could have a bigger income and save, because she would not have to buy as much milk from other people, as she would have it available for herself.

Roxana wants to have a child soon, and provide that child with everything he needs.  In addition, she wants to have her own cows and process more milk so that she can have a better income and provide a better life to her family.

loans.use: to buy a dairy cow

loans.name: José Edu

texts.es:
El señor José tiene 37 años de edad, es casado con tres hijos de tres y un año respectivamente.

Él tiene 5 meses de haber instalado una tienda de productos de la canasta básica. La mercadería la compra en una ciudad del oriente del país, viaja dos veces por semana, porque vende bastante, para llegar ahí tiene que recorrer 8 kilómetros, aborda dos microbuses.

José solicita el préstamo, para comprar por mayor: frijoles, sopas instantáneas, jabón, aceite, azúcar, lejía, detergentes, entre otros más. Su esposa es quien atiende a los clientes y ella se siente muy optimista por el negocio. También el préstamo lo utilizaran en la compra de tambos de gas propano, para cocinar, por que solo tienen cinco y quieren comprar otros cinco más, ya que el proveedor pasa cada 8 días. 

Con el préstamo ahorra tiempo y dinero, ya que viajara menos a la ciudad y los clientes se le incrementan cada día, por lo que necesita tener mercadería.

Él desea tener una tienda sólida y que le genere ingresos suficientes, para no seguir trabajando como seguridad privada, ya que considera que es un trabajo muy peligroso.
texts.en:
José is 37 years old, married and has three children, ages three and one, respectively.

He’s been running a general store for the past five months.  He buys his merchandise in the town to the west, traveling there twice a week because he has good sales.  He must travel 8 km by bus to get there.

José is asking for this loan in order to buy beans, instant soup, soap, cooking oil, sugar, bleach, detergents, and other things.  His wife serves the customers and she feels very optimistic about the business.  They will also use some of the money to buy cylinders of propane gas for cooking.  At the moment they only have five and would like five more because the provider only comes once a week.

This loan saves him time and money because he will not have to travel to town as often and his customer base increases daily and he needs to have merchandise.

He would like to have a solid store that generated sufficient income for him so that he will not have to continue working as a private security guard, as he considers that to be a dangerous job.

loans.use: to buy inventory.

loans.name: Philomene

texts.fr:
Cliente de 55 ans, celibataire et mère de 5 enfants dont deux sont encore sur le banc de l'école. Elle s'est lancée dans la vente des vêtements et layette il y'a de cela 30 ans, quand elle se sépare avec le père de ses enfants.
Donc pour subvenir a ses besoins et prendre soin de ses enfants, elle ouvre un étalage et renforce son activité lorsqu'elle obtient le premier prêt de Hope, elle renforce son activité et se fait un capital et ses ventes augmentent automatiquement, parce qu'elle ne prenait plus a crédit, elle s'approvisionnait dans les grandes boutiques de la place.
Avec ce nouveau prêt, elle fera autant, et achète tous ce qui est nécessaire pour les nouveaux nés.les bavoirs, les pulls, ensemble de tricot, barboteuses, couvertures, couches...

Elle a pour objectif d'ouvrir une grande boutique et devenir grossiste, elle s'occupe valablement de ses enfants, et elle est prise comme modèle des femmes dans son quartier.
texts.en:
This client is a 55-year-old single woman and the mother of five children, two of whom are still at school. She began selling clothing and babywear some thirty years ago, when she separated from the father of her children. 

In order to cover her needs and to be able to take care of her children, she opened a stall and strengthened her business when she got her first loan from Hope. She grew the business, obtained working capital and her sales automatically increased, because she no longer bought on credit - she was able to purchase stock in the large stores in town. 

With this new loan, she will do the same, and will buy everything that newborn babies need - bibs, jumpers, knitted outfits, romper suits, blankets and diapers, etc. 

Her goal is to open a large store and to become a wholesaler. She takes good care of her children and is seen as something of a role model among the women in her neighbourhood.

loans.use: To buy children's outfits, diapers, and other clothing for resale

loans.name: Yahia's Group

texts.en:
Yahia's group is comprised of two hard-working women. Yahia is 18 years old and lives in the town of Kachwamba in the Fort Portal region of Uganda. She is single and has one child who is currently in school. For the past year and seven months, Yahia has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells food and household supplies to local customers.
